reviewText:
I remember so long ago when I first heard about this game from a friend of mine and began reading up on it that this game could have the potential for being one of those rare gems that could singlehandedly revitalize the platforming genre. I remember playing the demo for this and having the biggest nostalgia-gasm I ever had. And when I hung around through so two versions of the demo, I found myself raising a brow at it a few different times at the changes the guys over at GalaxyTrail made to the game, then did a little backtracking to other versions of the demo and seeing how far its come along since then, from being a Sonic fangame to something far different, something that needed to attain its own identity. And to be honest, it has earned that right in spades.

The colors are vibrant, almost as if it blends every color of the rainbow into an extravagant feast for the eyes. The characters are all likable, the music is an absolute blast to listen to, everything about this game hits every single mark that it should and then some. Sure, the physics of the game kinda feels a little bit on the heavy side, but everything seems as though everything was given the proper weight, the exact amount of impact and damage severity.

So what criticisms can I lob at this game, now that I have it in my possession? To tell the honest truth, I really can't! It feels like if I were to try to nitpick at this game, I feel as though it'll only prove me wrong with a righteous backhand across the face. I might amend this as I go along, but for now, this game is something you owe yourself to pick up right now, sit down and revel in this roller coaster ride!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
An absolutely fantastic action platformer adventure with a cute and fun story that isn't afraid to have its darker moments, endearing and varied characters with very challenging boss fights and a nice length to boot!

This is an excellent experience for nostalgic platformer fans and a refreshing surprise for those like me who find that even the most well-recieved 2D titles are simply not to their tastes.

As someone who can never really find more than a minute or two of enjoyment from 2D games, from the Sonics of yesteryear to the more recent such as Super Meat Boy, Starbound,  Hotline Miami, etc. I would highly suggest giving Freedom Planet a try, It gets right what all of those others fall short on for me; but perhaps consider lowering the difficulty as normal can sometimes become a little masochistic.

It turned out to be the most fun I've had in 2014 and I sincerely feel it is one of the rare games deserving of a sequel.

reviewText:
At first glance, it might be tempting to dismiss Freedom Planet as a rip-off of the old Genesis Sonic games.  But while it's clear that those games did provide a lot of inspiration for this one, such a dismissal is a disservice to an excellent piece of entertainment.  While its level layouts, character designs, and gameplay definitely take cues from Sonic, Freedom Planet is its own game.  It's less about speed and more about exploration, control, and combat, a game that rewards observation and thinking in addition to quick reflexes.

The game's bosses deserve special mention.  While the first few are fairly simple fights that one can clear without much effort, the latter half of the game features some genuinely challenging fights that require speedy reactions and good pattern memorization.  They're very challenging without being unfair, and are, on the whole, superb.

There's a story too, and it isn't bad, but it's secondary to the game's beautiful aesthetics and great gameplay.  If you're a fan of challenging, old-school platformers, it's hard to go wrong with Freedom Planet.

reviewText:
Wonderful. Sidescrolling, platforming combat that will remind you of the best that Sonic and Gunstar Heroes ever had to offer. Everything about this game drips sincerity. In a time where irony and self aware parody are done to death, it's extremely refreshing to play a game who's story and characters are fueled by a genuine love and pride in the material without obligatory 4th wall breaks.

-Beautiful Sprites
-Energetic Soundtrack
-Cool Boss Fights(remember boss fights?)
-Passionate Voiceovers

The story offers a good blend of personal, and big picture elements. As an adult who's been layered in cynicism, I could occasionally find myself nitpicking a cliche, or contrivance, but for someone as nitpicky as myself that's an impressive feat. Further, the aformentioned sincerity of the game makes these complaints dissolve. Every tone the game touches is done so in an unironic, passionate way. The cool is supposed to be cool, the joy joyful, and the sadness heartfelt. A wonderful testament to the fact indie doesn't have to mean snobby and joyless.

Moving through the stages is exciting and satisfying, thanks to curved surfaces, ramps, and your own air boost. The way you move is one thing that gets this game pegged as a Sonic clone, and while I'd be surprised if there wasn't a page or two taken from classic Sonic games, that's hardly a gripe. They took something that worked and did it one better. Stage designs are not overly punishing for you not memorizing them, as is the case in classic Sonic. Calling it a Sonic clone is a decent shortcut to explaining movement, but sells the game very short. If a Sonic game ever came out on the level of this game, the world would lose it's mind.

You'd have to be blind not to see where the character designs would fit right into Sonic's world, but they look great, and even if you don't look at this as anything but a fan-game it's still a joy to play. Watch the trailers, it's twice as fun as it looks. Recommended even at full price.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pure 16-bit joy.
If you have fond memories of older games, especially Sonic, your going to shudder in absolute sheer pleasure starting this game up. The graphics are lovingly detailed to give the perfect vibe from the glory days of gaming.

But wait! Its not really like Sonic at all (despite the outward appearance)! Characters can fight enemies much more effectively than Sonic ever could, with cool looking melee attacks and even a guage for their special ability. They can even swim underwater instead of bouncing around helplessly. And the boss battles. Oh god the boss battles. Their all insanely varied and if your playing on Hard Mode , your in for some intense, high octane challenges. Once you persevere, its such a great feeling of accomplishment.

This game also OOZES personality from every sweet pore. The story is cute and at times genuinely affecting with the characters all vibrant and brought to life by great voice acting. Some people may not enjoy certain voices, but I find they fit the characters just fine.

TO TOP IT ALL OFF the soundtrack in this game is absolutely phenomenal, I can't find anything bad to say about Freedom Planet's music. Every track fits the level just right and its a likely chance you'll have some of these tunes sneaking onto your Ipod.

Overall, I rarely write reviews, but this game deserves my fullest reccomendation. I genuinely hope and wish for a sequel and for Freedom Planet to become a long-running franchise, its genuinely deserved. Games like this and Shovel Knight are what the gaming industry desperately needs right now.

reviewText:
Freedom Planet blew me away. I found it to be both a nostalgia trip as well as very well put together in its own right. I would even go out to say that it is more to my liking then the Genesis Sonic games which it seems inspired by. I believe the biggest reason for this is the story, which I found quite enjoyable. It did have a few portions that were a little rushed feeling or not as deeply explored as I would have liked but it was still one of the best parts.

The gameplay was also really sharp. I found the combat mechanics to be a breath of fresh air in a platformer of this nature. Also the fact that running into most enemies didn't hurt you unless they were actively attacking gave this game multiple ways to play. It allowed you to bypass most enemies if you wanted to, while giving you a good combat mechanic if you did want to defeat them instead. The best place in this game is infact in the combat, in the form of bosses. I found them to be creative and interesting, with each one making me learn different strategies that would come in later bosses as well. That being said, there was on in particular where I felt the difficulty jumped far too high just due to the high amount of damage it could do in a single hit.

Graphically this game is a joy to behold. You can tell each character and background had a lot of effort poured into them. The colors are vibrant, and most of the work has a lot of detail. That being said there are a few issues I had, mostly with the larger bosses. most of them seemed to be lacking a bit of the sharper look everything else had. They still looked good, but not great like the rest.

The sound track was very well put together. It flowed near seamlessly through levels, with each one doing a good job at setting the tone. One of the final levels themes was an exception, while it was one of my favorite tracks it had an obvious moment it looped. It broke a bit of the seamless feel. Another note is that while the music is rather good, only a couple tunes really stood out to me and made me want to listen to them outside of the game.

The biggest surprise the game had however was the voice acting. Besides a couple voices, they were all very well done. Particularly the playable characters and the main villain. I have to put out special props to the voice actress for Milla. I usually dislike higher pitched characters in games as they tend to be lower quality then the rest of the cast. This was an exception for certain. I found the character more endearing due to the voice as opposed to annoyed.

Overall I found this game to be a great one, and I would definately reccomend it to anyone who likes oldschool platformers, especially those in line with Sonic the Hedgehog.

reviewText:
In this good old fashion 2D platformed, its up to Soni....er...Lilac the Dragon to recover the Chaos....um....Kingdom Stone from the evil Doctor Egg....I mean....Lord Brevon.

OK, in all seriousness, this game did start out as more or less a Sonic fan game, but it was also always really intended to be it's own thing. The game is well paced and simply a lot of fun to play, with a good story.  The Sonic influence shows, but the game also feels like it has it's own identity.

Critics of the game like to criticize the physics and speed.  Yes, it's not often you actually do go super top speed in this game, but it's also not often you need to.  Even though you don't move at the speed of sound, you never feel like your moving too slow. (and I think you still move faster than some of the classic Sonic games.) There are times you kind of walk up walls, (you really only need momentum and a slope to get up walls, no matter how little speed you actually have), but I find that to be more helpful than bad.  And as for Carol the Wildcat's bike....well, breaking the laws of Physics is just one of it's features.

Each playable character is fun to use, and different enough that it actually warrants playing each stage with each character.  Each character also has there own story, which shows you extra story tidbits.   (well, at the time of writing this, Milla doesn't have a story mode, but she will soon, and new playable character are planned too.) And each character has a level exclusively to them. (well, Carol doesn't get one all to herself, but there is one clearly designed with her in mind.)

The story itself is great.  Yes, it's a bit cheesy, but it's in the style of a classic early 90's Saturday cartoon.  Cheesy but also serious at points.  It works well.  There were defiantly moments that had me laughing, and other moments that had me on the edge of my seat.  Of course if you just hate story in retro platformers you can always play classic, and just skip the story.

The voice acting is good.  Maybe not the best ever (I wouldn't even begin to claim to be an expert in that department), but defiantly not the worst voices I've ever heard.  Defiantly quality work.

Overall this game has a classic feel and charm, but at the same time feels fresh and new.  I didn't really feel that nostalgic when playing this.  Maybe that's because I entered the video game world in the N64/PS1 era (save some original NES), or maybe it's because I was too caught up in the game itself as a title today.  Freedom Planet gets a 10/10, and is a great game for anyone who loves Sonic platformers, Retro platformers, or just 2D platformers in general.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Freedom Planet is a platformer that takes on an identity to resemble the old Sonic the Hedgehog games on the Sega Genesis(Mega Drive). It has the sense of speed of those games with the simple platforming and gravity defying movement. Despite that, it is strictly not a Sonic clone. The characters in this game play quite differently and there's more of a choose your own flavor in this game. You can explore the levels at your own pace, or try to set speed records by zipping through them as fast as possible.\nThe boss battles are some of the most fun things about this game, with a great sense of difficulty and this game even has difficulty settings if you find it too rough for you. Anyone can get into this game and play it quickly without the story or just enjoy the simple storyline.\nFreedom Planet is a game that one should try if they love fast paced 2d action platforming. I wholly recommend it for carving out its own identity and making us forget about that blue hedgehog that hasn't seen better days for over a decade.

reviewText: When first looking at Freedom Planet I honestly didn't expect much other than a Sonic clone. It had the old-school feel, some familiar patterns in what was seen of the levels in the trailers and on screenshots. reviewText:
Remember those days of Fast sonic games in the 1990's? The amazing sound of Genesis games and amazing story?

Personal Rating: 50 / 10. A game that deserves more than a perfect Rating. It needs a sequel, a television series, more merchandise. It's a game I want more of


--- In-depth Review below ---

Before I start, this game has a difficulty selection. So what I say here comes from Normal Difficulty. ^^

Imagine them with an in-depth story like a successful television series, add a variety of bosses that are not only different, but aren't pushovers; then split the story up to 3 character (so far), told by their perspective (Replayable? Definitely!) and then as music that's so stunning and amazing, that it should have it's own album. ( Currently on Bandicamp ). That is Freedom Planet.

A combination of Sonic gameplay, Jazz jackrabbit music, Kung fu panda characters with a breathtaking story. What's better than that?

Only an additional time trial, secrets, unlockables, different characters having different routes in the same levels and for STEAM ONLY (So far), a collection of trading cards that pretty much amazing by themselves.

Oh and you remember how common enemies are easy to kill with a dash or jumping on their head?

Not going to work. Each enemy has a unique pattern completely different from the last; no reskins, copied A.i. here, completely unique and original enemy design and gameplay.

I haven't even beaten 1 character yet and the story feels as satisfying as watching adventure time, sonic SATAM or any popular television show at this time. (The game is so amazing, I want it to last ^^ )

It's a game that leaves you wanting more!

reviewText:
This game has the same magic that catapaulted the classic Sonic games to fame. The characters feel like extensions of you - not an avatar that you are manipulating. Slopes let you catapault to soaring heights, and you can blast through a stage once you learn it. If you're like me and have been waiting since 1994 for an honest successor to those games, your wait is over. It easily rivals Sonic 3 and Knuckles as one of the greatest platform games ever made. You don't need to wait for this one to go on sale - it is worth far more than its launch price.

This isn't to say that it is a Sonic clone - in some ways it is, but in other ways it is completely unique. The parts of the game that could qualify as 'sonic cloning' are cloned so well that the brilliance of the originals shine through. All of the parts that are unique are thoughtfully designed and fit in with the whole.

As a fellow game developer, my only critique is that I would tweak the checkpoint system a little bit. There were many times where a checkpoint would occur just a little bit too early before a boss fight or other notable encounter, which would slow me down when I wanted to just get back into the action. I'd make it abit more like Nitronic Rush or Super Meat Boy with the 'immediately back in the action' principle. Still, this is a trivial issue and doesn't detract from the experience at all.

reviewText:
When I first saw this game on the steamstore I said to myself, whoa, where did this come from? I took a closer look and saw screenshots that brought up fond memories of Sonic the Hedgehog, Gunstar Heroes, and Sparkster. Then I watched the trailer, had my mind blown and immediately reached for the buy button. This game is simply awesome!

Remember that thrill of searching stages for stuff at high speeds in Sonic? You get that here. Remember fighting those tough but awesome Sparkster and Gunstar Heroes bosses? That's here too! Remember finding cool secrets by carefully using wall climbing and airdashes in Megaman X? Tons of that goodness here! This game delivers almost all the great experiences of classic 2d gaming in 1 package.

Even if you don't have memories of all these games, this game delivers some excellent 2d gameplay and you shouldn't pass it up. Everything about this game shows that a TON of love went into it's development. Get it and enjoy! Tell your friends about it if you like it!

reviewText:
I never did one of these reviews for any of my games on Steam but I felt I had to this time. This is definitely worth the 15 dollars and for me it was money well spent for this game.
Not only look but plays like a game that would have been a classic on the Sega Saturn. I mean the GOOD SS games too. There are a lot of familiar gameplay elements that do borrow from the classic Sonic and Sega games. Not to mention great soundtrack with large and colorful levels and some very good voice acting. Not talking Acedemy Awards quality but a heck of a lot better than what you probably heard in the Playstation and Sege Saturn era.
You also start of with two characters with very different movesets. I unlocked another character with a different moveset as well and they are pretty diverse in their attacks and specials. The sprite animation is top quality as well and the controls are very resonsive so yeah not floaty or slidey character movements. You can tell this is a game the developers put a lot of love into because it does not feel like an indie game at all.


So if you want a good quality throwback platformer from the 90s I cannot recommend this game enough.

reviewText:
Mix together Sonic+Megaman X+Sparkster/Rocket Knight+Pulseman heck, a bit of Chip and Dale with Millia (one of the three characters in this game) and some of Treasure's magic together and you have a heck of a crazy game here. This game feels like the devs heisted people from the Saturn era to bring a game that not only looks but feels like an old school platformer.

That's not to say it's like other games claiming 'retro', no this one actually has the feel, the characters have the ol' Genesis/Playstation/Saturn era weight/ feel of 2D platformers. No havok physics engine just whatever the heck made them feel like they did.

Fun levels, awesome music, cheesy cutscenes and gimmicks that don't require obscure hardware to make fun. Took around 3 hours to beat the first time through (took my time, was enjoying the game) and there's 2 other characters to beat it with. Lots of different routes to go with this game and replayablilty to bring you back.

Speaking of the characters, all 3 of them play differently.
Lilac runs, jumps, kicks, has a double jump that acts as a spin attack lasting till she hits the ground, she can uppercut or kick down (which can speed you up if you do it down hill).  Then her her dragon dash which spins her up and fires her off in a direction Rocket Knight style where she'll bounce off walls and smash enemies which relies on her power gauge.
The gauge very quickly (5 seconds maybe?) making her very mobile.

The other Carol, is able to wall hop Megaman X style, claw around a bunch and ride a bloody motorcycle that does spin jumps like Sonic, can drive it up walls and up ladders and ...it's so cheesy and damn fun becase of it. The motorcycle is a powerup and can be lost and regained by gas tanks laying about.

So I got to play as the third character, Milla. She's very different in terms of gameplay  she floats like Yoshi, throws blocks Chip-N-Dale style and can form shields to bounce enemy attacks or even turn her block into a big short ranged beam. She's the only character so far who does not use a special bar and it's fun. Her boss fights are also drastically different since you're not as agile or offensively able.

The game clearly has a LOT of effort behind it, there's a lot of detail put into the game like holding a button to access bloopers while the story is playing out. Dancing around disco balls while fun music plays. My favorite: while in some boss fights your friends will come in to help you fight, Carol leaping in on her motorcycle to kick the boss and Milla straight up dropping health from a plane. It's really charming to see all this in action.


If you're going to blow off this game because it looks like a Sonic ripoff you're missing out because that's not what the game is.

Brilliant game and I hope to see more from the creators. $15 gets you around 3 hours for one character playthrough and for those who skipped to the end here, each plays very different and have some unique levels and paths in stages the others have.

Edited: To talk about the third character

reviewText:
This is a game I would recommend to anyone who is interested in fast paced platformers.  From the level design to the art, from the music to the sound effects, everything about this game oozes excellence.

There is never a dull moment in this game, in particular the boss fights are jaw droppingly good, and will definitely leave an impression on you, which is to say nothing about the accompanying soundtrack, which I've been replaying nonstop since its release in July.

I like this game so much, that I would go so far as to say this is my Game of the Year 2014, because not only has it met my expectations, it has exceeded them.

reviewText: Freedom Planet is a retro-style platformer, originally designed to be a Sonic the Hedgehog fan game, only to evolve into a love letter to retro platformers in its own right. I'm happy to say this game is not too busy wearing rose-tinted nostalgia glasses to provide an entertaining challenge and a sense of childlike wonder when you first play it. It isn't so busy kissing retro gamers' feet to provide a satisfying game in its own right.\n\nSo what does Freedom Planet do right? I mentioned childlike wonder
date: and the game certainly provides this in spades. Though dialogue between characters is immensely cheesy, it ironically manages to add to the game's appeal. The writing is not exactly sterling, and pretty much is exactly what I would expect from a game on Sega Genesis, which - given the aesthetic - is probably what GalaxyTrail was going for.\n\nThe gameplay is divided amongst three different characters, who each have a unique style of play. Lilac, the spunky dragonoid
recommended:
is a more offensive character who has the ability to basically spin dash in the air and ricochet off of walls, which is necessary in order to progress through levels. Similarly, Carol - the cat girl - has the ability to wall-jump, and has a motorcycle for a power-up that can drive up walls and ceilings, as well as use red platforms to jump between walls. The basset hound, Milla, is unlocked not even after progressing halfway through the game, which makes you wonder why the developer would even gate her off to begin with. Regardless, she has a much more unique style of play from the others. She can use ranged attacks, produce a shield to block attacks, and has the ability to fly for a short period of time, similar to Tails of Sonic fame. Each character has a health bar, but Milla has a decidedly smaller one, supposedly keeping with the theme that she isn't much of a fighter.

The inspirations from Sonic the Hedgehog are made abundantly clear in this game, and yet, the game has a far greater focus on platforming than speed, unlike many of the newer Sonic games. In fact, I would argue even unlike the original Sonic games. Speed almost takes a backseat: you aren't necessarily rewarded a ranking at the end of each level for how quickly you can complete a level. It's worth fighting enemies, as they tend to drop blue gems which you can collect to get extra lives (kind of like a retro platformer, huh?), but instead of 100, you must collect 150. Some enemies drop orbs which can be collected to unlock a bonus stage at the end of each level where you roll a die that you can hit repeatedly in order to reroll and hopefully get a different reward, whether it be a plethora of shields or 1-ups.

Speaking of shields, like the Sonic games, this game does have shield powerups, but they're rather unintuitive. There are several to choose from, and they all block you from taking damage, but what exactly the function of each one is is up to you to find out. A yellow, polygonal shield in the game lets you collect gems from a distance, a blue shield producing bubbles lets you breathe indefinitely underwater (an aside, this game has the most intuitive swimming controls I've seen in a platformer in some time), and a silver shield, fire shield, and pink sakura blossom shield that seem to make you invulnerable to certain attacks (the silver shield protects you from taking damage from spikes).

All of these mechanics come together to produce a retro platformer that is hard to forget, and that I find myself booting up repeatedly just to play through the same levels over and over again just to get better. It's a challenging platformer, the likes of which I simply don't see much of anymore - at least from the Mario and Sonic franchises. The absolutely stellar soundtrack composed by Woofle and the beautiful Genesis-era aesthetic are icing on the cake. Each level is nicely varied with its own, unique mechanics, and each boss provides an almost controller-biting challenge. One caveat, however, is that these bosses seem to have a slightly wonky difficulty curve, creating this curious scenario where a boss six levels into the game is somehow easier than one from two levels ago. I'm willing to chalk this up to subjectivity: whoever play-tested the game probably thought the bosses were the perfect difficulty curve, but I found ways to easily exploit some of them. Except the final boss, of course: he's impossible to fight if you don't practice.

At an MSRP of $15, I'm shocked at how few people own a copy of Freedom Planet. It's one of the best platformers of recent memory, up there with everyone's darling Shovel Knight. It's challenging, but not hardcore punishing in the way a game like Super Meat Boy might be. You'll have plenty of fun exploring the different levels, trying to best a boss without taking any damage, or even gathering all the collectible cards. (I guess it wouldn't be a platformer without collectibles...) Top it off with the most convincing retro stylization I've seen in a game attempting to appeal to retro sensibilities, and I find it impossible not to recommend.

This game was Kickstarted, but don't let that put you off of one of the best platformers of all time. If you're anything like me, you'll find yourself in absolute delight playing this game. The fact that it hasn't had anywhere near as much press as other fantastic indie games like Shovel Knight is almost criminal, to me. I can only hope my review will convince some people to pick it up and discover for themselves a love letter to Sonic fans that doesn't try desperately to clone the franchise it's inspired by. It's a better Sonic game than any of the recent Sonic games, and it's not even trying to be. I don't know if I could possibly praise this game enough.

Please, buy Freedom Planet. If you enjoy retro platformers, you will not regret this one.

reviewText:
I remember so long ago when I first heard about this game from a friend of mine and began reading up on it that this game could have the potential for being one of those rare gems that could singlehandedly revitalize the platforming genre. I remember playing the demo for this and having the biggest nostalgia-gasm I ever had. And when I hung around through so two versions of the demo, I found myself raising a brow at it a few different times at the changes the guys over at GalaxyTrail made to the game, then did a little backtracking to other versions of the demo and seeing how far its come along since then, from being a Sonic fangame to something far different, something that needed to attain its own identity. And to be honest, it has earned that right in spades.

The colors are vibrant, almost as if it blends every color of the rainbow into an extravagant feast for the eyes. The characters are all likable, the music is an absolute blast to listen to, everything about this game hits every single mark that it should and then some. Sure, the physics of the game kinda feels a little bit on the heavy side, but everything seems as though everything was given the proper weight, the exact amount of impact and damage severity.

So what criticisms can I lob at this game, now that I have it in my possession? To tell the honest truth, I really can't! It feels like if I were to try to nitpick at this game, I feel as though it'll only prove me wrong with a righteous backhand across the face. I might amend this as I go along, but for now, this game is something you owe yourself to pick up right now, sit down and revel in this roller coaster ride!

reviewText:
To start, I'd recommend you try to separate this game from others because the changes might result in frustrating habits.

In short, this game has excellent sounds, visuals, and a very adaptable gameplay style with challenging enemies (both mooks and bosses) and great level design. It's strongest aspects for me is the pacing of the game that is helped immensely by it's soundtrack and audio, gameplay rules that allow yourself and enemies to be on equal footing, and a story that is not distilled for the sake of being harmless.

The story does not try to force morals and lessons on you but instead gives you a interesting, fun, and animated experience that I feel I can say attempts elements that aren't typically featured in such a cartoony setting.

Gameplay-wise, most of the opponents are dangerous, down to the most dormant and the level design is varied. Often you will come across situations where enemies will challenge your speed in ways that will require you to fight, use an ability, change direction, slow down, or keep to your speed until you can escape. I feel it noteworthy to mention that enemies do not damage you on contact unless they clearly can. There are moments of slow platforming and times where you can progress at a relaxing pace with each character having their own methods of progress and are equally well equipped to do so. I also appreciate that bosses act a lot like they look as a human" boss does not rely on soaking up hits or ramming into you as much as a robot or a manned machine.



This game

recommended: is a great blend of many game practices and I would easily recommend it. Thanks for reading."

reviewText:
At the first glance, Freedom Planet is a Sonic clone. While it was certainly inspired by Sonic, it is in no way a clone. While it included the high speed platforming people have come to know and love, it also brings along something that classic Sonic never featured: free-flowing combat. All of the characters have simple attacks and a special move they can pull off that can help them fight enemies and bosses. This certainly bring a new element to the Sonic-like play style, so you can be acrobatic while still fighting; however, to compensate for this, bosses and enemies have more complicated attack patterns that may take some time to get used to, which may lead to frustration.

There was a lot of care that went into the production of this game. The sprite work is beautifully done. It pops with bright colors and details. The music is well composed and fits the tone of the levels. The levels themselves are unique and diverse. All of these combine to make a masterpiece. The cutscenes, on the other hand, are not as magnificent. The animation behind them aren't that spectacular, the story isn't grand, and the voice acting is a little mediocre. Don't get me wrong, they can be a nice diversion from the rest of the game and they were certainly better that what I was expecting, but at times I just wanted to get back to playing the game. Thankfully, there is a game mode that lets you skip all the cutscenes.

Overall, this game is amazing. First time players may have a tough time adjusting to the game play, especially the bosses' attack patterns, but will still have enough fun that will override any frustration. If you didn't get your dose of Sonic from Sonic Boom (honestly, who did?), then give this game a try.

reviewText:
A fun and well-made game, one of the best platformers I've seen in a while. Every aspect of this game is excellent.

Great level design is its best feature. Levels are all huge (when you feel like you should be getting close to the end of the level in a normal game, you're probably near the halfway point), nonlinear and secret-filled. They also all have unique hazards and features you can interact with, from platforms that move when you touch them to slot machines and giant dandelion seeds. Level design virtually never punishes you for going fast in an area that looks like you're meant to go fast except by making you miss items (you'll never barrel into spikes or fire or enemies), which is important with all the inspiration it takes from Sonic.

The soundtrack is also top-notch, and both the bosses and regular enemies are well designed. Each character plays differently with their own attacks and abilities, and there's a few levels you'll only see with one character with extra focus on their abilities. All three characters feel versatile and fun. There's a level select once you've beaten the game, and an option to skip all the story cutscenes (which is a good thing, since the story is the one thing in this game that's not especially good). Difficulty can be adjusted as needed.

To sum up: This game is excellent in every way a game can be excellent, and FUN. Buy it!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a real treat.  What started as a Sonic tribute game has taken threads and swatches from several of the best platforming experiences of the SNES/Genesis era and woven together a brilliant game that's every bit the equal of its retro inspiration.

The music and voice acting are commendable making this worth repeat playthroughs just to hear some of the level tunes again.  Top notch character animations deserve to be singled out.  Sprites are very emotive and easily allow you to empathize with the characters.  Control is also very solid.  The physics feel appropriate, giving you adequate control over your characters.  They're even adjusted in several places to avoid breaking the flow of the action, like allowing you to run up a wall at slow speeds to avoid making you have to back up and get a perfect running start.  It's a great improvement over many Sonic games.

The amount of love and care that's gone into this game rivals the best of Nintendo's work.  It would be a shame if you didn't at least download the demo and give it a try.  This one's worth every penny of its price.

reviewText:
At the first glance, Freedom Planet is a Sonic clone. While it was certainly inspired by Sonic, it is in no way a clone. While it included the high speed platforming people have come to know and love, it also brings along something that classic Sonic never featured: free-flowing combat. All of the characters have simple attacks and a special move they can pull off that can help them fight enemies and bosses. This certainly bring a new element to the Sonic-like play style, so you can be acrobatic while still fighting; however, to compensate for this, bosses and enemies have more complicated attack patterns that may take some time to get used to, which may lead to frustration.

There was a lot of care that went into the production of this game. The sprite work is beautifully done. It pops with bright colors and details. The music is well composed and fits the tone of the levels. The levels themselves are unique and diverse. All of these combine to make a masterpiece. The cutscenes, on the other hand, are not as magnificent. The animation behind them aren't that spectacular, the story isn't grand, and the voice acting is a little mediocre. Don't get me wrong, they can be a nice diversion from the rest of the game and they were certainly better that what I was expecting, but at times I just wanted to get back to playing the game. Thankfully, there is a game mode that lets you skip all the cutscenes.

Overall, this game is amazing. First time players may have a tough time adjusting to the game play, especially the bosses' attack patterns, but will still have enough fun that will override any frustration. If you didn't get your dose of Sonic from Sonic Boom (honestly, who did?), then give this game a try.

reviewText:
Earlier in 2014 the indie gaming scene was graced with a charming title that harked back to an era many of us hold dear, that of the Nintendo Entertainment System. Shovel Knight from Yacht Club Games delighted retro gamers and newcomers alike with its classic NES like charm, wonderful retro soundtrack and cleverly constructed levels, polished off with a unique art style that celebrates games of the late 80s. Now it seems that it’s the early 90s turn to shine with Freedom Planet, a title from indie developer Galaxy Trail that harks back to the era of a console I hold very dear, the Sega Megadrive (otherwise known as the Genesis in the US).

Freedom Planet clearly takes great inspiration from many Sega Megadrive games, most notably Sonic The Hedgehog which the bulk of its gameplay elements seem to mimic. It also evokes memories of Treasure’s fantastic platform shooter Gunstar Heroes with much of its design and there are even elements of Capcom’s Mega Man X series, so there’s a little bit of Super Nintendo love in there somewhere too. The 90s nostalgia doesn’t stop there either, Freedom Planet’s art style and story is reminiscent of early 90s cartoons such as Bucky ‘O Hare with its tale of anthropomorphic freedom fighters taking on a militaristic threat to the galaxy, this time in the form of intergalactic overlord Brevon, an insectoid tyrant with dreams of absolute, intergalactic domination. This cartoon like feel is further captured in the way the story is told as it follows the three protagonists, Lilac (an anthropomorphic dragon), Carol (an anthropomorphic cat) and Milla (an anthropomorphic basset hound) who are portrayed as innocent, adolescent characters finding themselves thrust into a dangerous war that their sense of right forces them to engage.

The gameplay of Freedom Planet flows beautifully. Much like the Sonic series it pays homage to, much of the game involves racing around levels collecting gems and smashing your way through enemies at high speeds. Level designs are colourful and large ranging from a lush rainforest shrouding trap filled Aztec ruins to a bustling Chinese styled city in the middle of a celebratory festival, each level boasts new and interesting mechanics to get to grips with and a nice variety of enemies to fight. Boss battles too are cleverly thought out, a joy to look at and offer a significant, fast paced challenge that really gets the adrenaline pumping. The games three protagonists control somewhat differently, Lilac feels very much like a Sonic character with her ability to pinball around levels whereas Carol feels more like a Mega Man character with her ability to wall jump, she also has a Chun Li style kick attack that gives her more of a fighter like feel, Carol also has a motorbike that she can use upon finding gas cans scattered about the various levels, making her much faster than before and changing up her abilities slightly. Milla is a little more unique, she has the ability to create energy cubes that she can throw as projectiles, she can also create a small energy shield and has the ability to flap her ears to execute a type of double jump. Of the three main characters Lilac definitely feels like her play style fits the flow of the game best.

The soundtrack to Freedom Planet is definitely deserving of a mention, the music is absolutely phenomenal and with a whopping two hour OST (no small feat for such a small Indie project) you’re going to hear a number of great tunes that you’ll want to listen to again and again that really set the tone for every stage and situation. The voice acting is also great for such a small title, some of the actors are noticeably better than others, however the bulk of the voice acting is top notch, Lilac, Carol and Milla sound especially convincing and carry the tone of the story across well.

All in all for £10.99 (the game’s price on Steam as of the time of this review) you really can’t go wrong with Galaxy Trail’s Freedom Planet, especially if, like me, you’re a retro, platform fanatic who grew up during the Sega Megadrive era.  If this sounds like you then this nostalgic trip down memory lane is definitely a game worth looking into.

reviewText:
--- THE GOOD ---
+ Fast, fun combat and gameplay.
+ Fantastic soundtrack.
+ Likable characters / great character design.
+ Great level design and bosses.
+ Several difficulty levels to choose from.
+ Meaningful acheivements.
+ Time attack leaderboards.

--- THE NEUTRAL ---
... Voice acting ranges from amateur to decent.
... The overall plot.

--- THE BAD ---
Nothing stands out as bad to me.

--- THE VERDICT ---
Freedom Planet is an absolute gem that just happened to appear as recommended to me on Steam one day.  After trying the demo, it more than warranted the purchase.  The game got better from there and has since become my favorite game on Steam, and also my favorite game of 2015 so far.  While the game does have some troubles with finding a consistent tone with it's story, the characters are still well designed and very likable across the board.  Ultimately what pushed this game past Shovel Knight in terms of overall enjoyment is it's difficulty, which allowed me to play on a difficult setting from the get go.  That said, for people newer to games, there are easier difficulties as well, so everyone wins.  The gameplay feels like a mix between Sonic and Mega Man Zero/ZX.  If you're a Sonic fan looking for this to PLAY like Sonic, it's actually quite a bit different... actually more like Mega Man Zero/ZX in my eyes.  In conclusion, I cannot recommend this game more for fans of platformers or retro games, and anyone with a passing interest should definitely try the demo.  My only question is, when will Freedom Planet 2 come out?

RATING:  A

reviewText:
Freedom Planet blew me away. I found it to be both a nostalgia trip as well as very well put together in its own right. I would even go out to say that it is more to my liking then the Genesis Sonic games which it seems inspired by. I believe the biggest reason for this is the story, which I found quite enjoyable. It did have a few portions that were a little rushed feeling or not as deeply explored as I would have liked but it was still one of the best parts.

The gameplay was also really sharp. I found the combat mechanics to be a breath of fresh air in a platformer of this nature. Also the fact that running into most enemies didn't hurt you unless they were actively attacking gave this game multiple ways to play. It allowed you to bypass most enemies if you wanted to, while giving you a good combat mechanic if you did want to defeat them instead. The best place in this game is infact in the combat, in the form of bosses. I found them to be creative and interesting, with each one making me learn different strategies that would come in later bosses as well. That being said, there was on in particular where I felt the difficulty jumped far too high just due to the high amount of damage it could do in a single hit.

Graphically this game is a joy to behold. You can tell each character and background had a lot of effort poured into them. The colors are vibrant, and most of the work has a lot of detail. That being said there are a few issues I had, mostly with the larger bosses. most of them seemed to be lacking a bit of the sharper look everything else had. They still looked good, but not great like the rest.

The sound track was very well put together. It flowed near seamlessly through levels, with each one doing a good job at setting the tone. One of the final levels themes was an exception, while it was one of my favorite tracks it had an obvious moment it looped. It broke a bit of the seamless feel. Another note is that while the music is rather good, only a couple tunes really stood out to me and made me want to listen to them outside of the game.

The biggest surprise the game had however was the voice acting. Besides a couple voices, they were all very well done. Particularly the playable characters and the main villain. I have to put out special props to the voice actress for Milla. I usually dislike higher pitched characters in games as they tend to be lower quality then the rest of the cast. This was an exception for certain. I found the character more endearing due to the voice as opposed to annoyed.

Overall I found this game to be a great one, and I would definately reccomend it to anyone who likes oldschool platformers, especially those in line with Sonic the Hedgehog.

reviewText:
At a first glance, one would easily see this game as a poseur Sonic game. Trust me when I say that it's much better than pretty much any Sonic game in the franchise. Some will complain that it's a 'bit game', and to those people, I would like to remind that the current day and age is effectively a 'revival of the bit', so some humility to the undying style would be nice(though if you'll still complain, I will respect your opinions; this is the internet, after all...).

High points:
-A game whose fast-paced action style will invigorate fans of platformers and sidescrollers
-Well-balanced characters whose traits suit their styles of combat and exploration
-Immersive and catchy music

Tripping points:
-The story, admittedly, could have been better, but still keeps the feel of games in the Bit Console Wars(Sega vs. Nintendo)
-The final four levels come with a moderately steep learning curve, but by this point, the game will still be challenging you to develop accordingly, so you should be okay if you're playing well

With a free DLC coming within the next few months, at best, for Torque, Spade and Milla's story lines, this game's a good pick. It's colorful, it has a great soundtrack, and of course has its fair share of in-stage collectibles. If you want a good platformer, buy this. If you want to reminisce about the days of the Bit Console Wars, this game's great for that, too. And for those who really want the feel of a controller, there's ever-developing support for it. Galaxy Trail's flagship title is a good sign for the company, I'd say, and those who have played Strife's other works will be anticipating the next title in line.

reviewText:
Freedom Planet much like Shovel Knight, harkens to an earlier era of gaming. Whereas Shovel Knight was to the 8-bit NES era, Freedom Planet leans towards the late end of the 16-bit era, taking cues from games like Gunstar Heroes and Sonic the Hedgehog (in Particular Sonic 3 & Knuckles)
I heard about this game a long while ago, and was intstantly interested. However, the extent of my interaction with the game has been no more than the few hours I played today.
As a disclaimer, I play a lot of games, and absolutely love the original sonics, so my gaming level may be considered advanced (everyone has their strengths and weaknesses though) So take this as my opinion, there is no unbiased review folks.

The GoodLet us begin, this game is not just a mere ripoff, this game borrows some good things from 16 bit era games that you never realized mattered so much.

Tight controls - This game is extremely responsive, and the controls are solid. One thing from Sonic that was always important was he was never too floaty, the speed never exceeded an amount that made it difficult to play, and each button press connected properly. Freedom Planet copies this important detail.

Simple controls - The game does not overload you with controls, it keeps things pretty simple, but with unique controls for each character. You are limited in your moves, so it doesn't take a lot for you to figure out what you need to do, where.

Innovative Gameplay - Now, I say innovative" as a relative term - the game relies on 16-bit era game design as a model
recommended: it innovates. The unique combination of beat'em'up aesthetics with the speed of sonic creates a unique experience. One could also argue it takes the coin-hoarding from the latest entries into the "New Super Mario Bros" series.\n\nYour pace - The game never forces you to go that fast
hoursPlayed: the timer does not tick to an invisible deadline. This game does not use the improper and often misinformed recollection that "sonic games are about going fast" Instead

reviewText:
There is no reason to play classic Sonic anymore. This is it. This is the game changer. This is a love letter to all the retro Saturn and Genesis fans.

Every playable character in this game is unique and has their own way of approaching each situation in a very smart way. The momentum never feels stale and the design is beautiful. If you don't have nostalgia for the era it probably won't grab you as much but it will still be appreciated. There's one stage that has a piano that you can step on - which ahs been done before in the Adnvace series I think but it's still nice to see it implemented into the game.

I thought the story was going to be bad and with tired cliches that you usually see in these kinds of games and although some of them are present the overall story is surprisingly deep. The cutscenes are too long which I think a lot of people complain about. There seems to be a lot of filler and a lot of things could be told differently or cut out of the game all together, I'm glad it's there though, it was engaging and interesting.. and with the classic mode I can just play stage by stage while still retaining knowledge of what is happening. I feel like the adventure mode is a one time playthrough for me, to put everything into perspective. The real seller is the gameplay, and it does that very well.

I definitely recommend this game! If you like platformers there's no reason that this shouldn't be in your library. It's a lot of fun and I'm glad it's here

reviewText:
Did you ever play the Genesis as a kid? Or ever play a decent sonic game? Or rocket knight?

Then you'll love Freedom Planet. It's a 'retro'(and I use the term only to describe the aesthetic, the gameplay has depth and a pleasurable console-feel that's not boring or re-hashed) game with old Sega aesthetics and interesting mechanics on every level. There are multiple characters to play, time attack modes, speed run attempts, etc., and a surprisingly long story mode for such a small studio. A good comparison is Shovel Knight, only Freedom planet is an homage to old Genesis games rather than old nintendo staples.

Freedom Planet features intense, fast paced gameplay that follows its own internal old-game logic(you can run up and down sheer walls as long as you have the speed, rotate around large loops ala sonic, etc.), a refreshingly simple combat system, and almost every enemy is entirely unique in sprite and animation. There are numerous mini bosses, a large stable of end-stage bosses, and a ton of beautifully rendered stages to run around in, each of which are huge, sprawling, and give you the 'freedom' to zoom around in almost any direction.

The story has a very weird saturday-morning-but-adult vibe, with brightly colored characters and voice acting work that feels almost purposefully over the top and ham-y. It's a bit surprising how dark the story gets while maintaining a relatively child-like atmosphere. Some of the cutscenes do drag on, but there's an option to run the game sans cutscenes if all you want is to have fun and run the game again for time or simply just don't care about a story at all.

There are a lot of nice, professional polish touches to Freedom Planet. Many Bosses have cutscenes, but if you die you simply respawn a bit further back, and whne you approach the Boss they leap right into the combat without having to redo dialogue again.There are a ton of secrets, and everything is bright and well animated in lots of primary colors.  The game's pacing is frantic, but in a way that feels fun rather than rushed. Every level feels different in a good way, with new mechanics added almost before you've learned the last stage's unique playability.

It does have some problems though. Some might find the deviant-art-esque characters unappealing from an aesthetics point, and the dialogue can sometimes be cringeworthy. And certain environmental effects are instant-kills, which can be tempo-ruining, pulling you out of the game. However, these are all minor concerns in what is a surprising gem of a game that should please any of thsoe nostalgic for a game that plays start to finish with a satisfying saturday-morning-cartoon power of friendship storyline.

reviewText:
Freedom Planet - the moment I stepped into this game, I thought that it looked like a Sonic game, and according to the thousand-something other reviewers, I'm not alone. Avoiding the temptation of calling it a Sonic analog, what is Freedom Planet?

Freedom Planet is a 2d platformer with emphasis on speed and combat. Every girl is capable of going blindingly fast, so much that it can be hard to keep up with them; they can use this speed to climb up walls, outrun enemies, and soar up to otherwise hard-to-reach areas. There's no RPG element - the characters have all the powers needed to clear the game from the moment you pick them.

The protagonists each have their own little quirks that come out in the game's many cutscenes. Those that do not like the voice acting will be pleased to know that every cutscene can be skipped - those who do like cutscenes will find a pleasantly colorful story. Opinions will vary as to whether or not the writing is good, though it is the likeable characters which help pull everything together. For a game that is trying to keep its rating child-friendly, the villain is also surprisingly brutal; where some villains are content to yell I'll get you next time!" as the hero thwarts them
date: Lord Brevon acts as more of the "I don't think you really -need- to breathe right now" sort of antagonist.\n\nOne of the best aspects of the game would have to be the astoundingly well done sound track. Moody tracks play during tense combat-heavy levels

reviewText:
(Imagine this in the Honest Trailers voice)

Tired of Indie games that your friend insists is one of the best games ever, but only plays once every four years? Well, get ready for the indie game that your friend insists is one of the best games ever, and plays once every THREE years! It’s just that good.

Freedom Planet.

Freedom; a word the evokes uninhibited exploration. Planet; a word used to describe worlds so big, Pluto doesn’t make the cut anymore. Get ready to explore a sprawling Metroidvania that is worthy of its title... what? It’s a level-by-level platformer with no upgrades? Then why is it called Freedom Pla [cut]

Welcome to planet Avalice. Embark on an epic two-and-a-half hour adventure with your choice of character. Blaze through over ten stages as Girl Sonic…-Ristar...-Gunstar...-Ryu...-Dragon... Okay, that’s awesome. Leave something for your sidekick, why don’t you? [clip of sidekick driving a motorcycle up a wall] Nevermind.

Use your skills to speed through huge lovingly detailed levels with multiple paths, then spend eighty percent of your time stuck trying to defeat bosses again and again in vain because you’re too stubborn to lower the difficulty. Ughh, how am I supposed to beat this guy?! He just punches out of nowhere and takes half my health! I’m not even playing on Hard! Patch this already! Oh good, they did. All right! Time to download… wait, I already have it? NOOOOOOOO [cut]

Get ready to experience a loving homage to Sonic, Ristar, Treasure, and every other awesome Sega Genesis \ Mega Drive and Saturn game every made, with quarter-pipes, crazy loop-de-loop structures, high-speed launches,  sweet music and sound effects, elemental shields, the dread of running out of oxygen, really big lasers, really big explosions, really big bosses that shake the screen when they attack and lag the framerate when they die,  and those cool spiral elevators that were in..,. uh… Launch Base Zone? Hydrocity Zone? You know, that zone with the cool spiral elevators in it. They’re in this game.

Then watch it burn your childhood nostalgia into a crisp by pointing out all the problems your favourite games had, and fixing them with simple features like: difficulty selection, more than one useful move per character, a perky 1-up jingle that only plays when the mood calls for it, a reasonable difficulty curve that ****s with you on purpose instead of drunkenly stumbling between too easy and too hard, the ability to pause cut-scenes, the ability to skip cut-scenes, the ability to not accidentally skip cut-scenes just by looking at the controller funny, an icon that tells you when something’s about to kill you from off-screen WHY DON’T SONIC GAMES EVER HAVE THOSE?! [breath], and swimming.

Use your cunning to conserve your health bar and cherish health pick-ups like water in a desert… or play on Easy and watch as your health regenerates before your eyes. You might as well; the achievements don’t care. And you can change the difficulty any time you want. See? This cleared save file has 100 deaths because I played on Normal, but do you see the word “Normal” anywhere on there? For all you know, I lost all those lives on Casual. But trust me, you guys, it was on Normal.

Cringe, at a, well, honestly, a surprisingly well-fitting story featuring: Decapitations, Brainwashing, Worldwide War, Making New Friends, Political Intrigue, Wholesale Asskicking, Playful Teasing, Horrifying Mutations, Cold-Blooded Torture, and All-You-Can-Eat Sushi. Mmmmm. Sewwwwsh.

Once you’ve played out the Adventure Mode, take on a variety of extra modes such as: Classic Mode, which is Adventure Mode minus the cutscenes, Time Attack Mode, which is Classic Mode plus a level select menu, and… ummmm…

Then, hunt for 100 cards hidden throughout the game, and try to collect the achievements, which are one part speedruns, one part card collection, one part challenges that would be tough if you couldn’t do them on any difficulty, and three parts wacky bull**** like “notice our dance easter egg”, “let the AI partner get the last hit on this boss”, and the ultimate bragging rights reward: “stand on a ledge.”

But seriously you guys, you think I’d write a review this long for a game I think is just ok? No. It’s tons of fun. Buy it now!

Starring: [Lilac] “CYCLONE!”, [Carol] A Green Bobcat on a Motorbike, [Milla] Fluttercream, [Brevon] The Bad Guy From Galaxy Quest, [Torque] Plucky Duck, [Syntax] GladOS Knockoff Number 263, [Neera Li] Panda Tigress, [Spade] Panda Gambit, [Gong] Brooklyn Panda, [Dail] Another Panda? Geez, they’re doing fine here apparently.

Wutai Planet.

[clip of Jade Creek boss, playing as Carol] Okay, so they script it so she swoops in at the last moment and claims the last hit on the boss? Screw off, glory hog, I did all the work.

Score: 3\4. (Close to 3.5, but the default price point feels a little steep. I might need to change this score with future DLC)

reviewText:
like your oldschool games? add this to your library. the game may run on a sonic-fangame engine, but it's gameplay oozes more than just the blue blur's games. from Sparkster style dashing Lilac, who is probably the closest the game offers to what you might be thinking this game offers, to Carol and her punches, kicks, and walljumping and dash techniques, which ooze Zero's Z Saber... well, aside from the fact Carol does in fact have a motorbike that seems to bend physics.
for the most part, the gameplay is run and jump to the right and beat folks up along the way, but exploration is encouraged through collectable cards, and the occasional fork in the road where the path to go forward is blocked by stuff you need to do in side rooms, from simple puzzles to a trapped room, and even a few bosses. speaking of bosses, they do offer a nice challenge, even if you gotta learn the patterns and how they retaliate to damage to have a chance at beating them.
as to the story, so far it's an amusing adventure with interesting character development. not saying more about the plot because spoilers and the important stuff you need to know is in the intro and the steam cards/character biographies. oh, and to get the full story, you're going to have to play the game twice: one for each character the story lets you play as.

oh, and good luck trying to get the achievements. especially the speedrun and no death run. you might as well use arcade mode for that since it disables the cutscenes.

TL:DR; good retro style game that takes a bunch of games, puts it in a blender for a few moments, and bakes to nostalgic goodness. also collectables beg to be found, and the game offers a good challenge, especially when the bosses come into play.

pick it up.

this also applies to your Wii U owning buddies as well who refuse to go to the PC: it's getting a port to the Wii U and if the controls are as tight as they are on the PC with as flawless performance as it is on a compy, it is worth buying.

EDIT: seeing as i own a Wii U, i tried the preview build on it. needless to say, it works just as well on Nintendo's console as it does on a computer.

in addition, Milla has her own story in the works, and two characters are rising to the plate as heroes.

for free! +5 generosity!

reviewText:
Did you ever play the Genesis as a kid? Or ever play a decent sonic game? Or rocket knight?

Then you'll love Freedom Planet. It's a 'retro'(and I use the term only to describe the aesthetic, the gameplay has depth and a pleasurable console-feel that's not boring or re-hashed) game with old Sega aesthetics and interesting mechanics on every level. There are multiple characters to play, time attack modes, speed run attempts, etc., and a surprisingly long story mode for such a small studio. A good comparison is Shovel Knight, only Freedom planet is an homage to old Genesis games rather than old nintendo staples.

Freedom Planet features intense, fast paced gameplay that follows its own internal old-game logic(you can run up and down sheer walls as long as you have the speed, rotate around large loops ala sonic, etc.), a refreshingly simple combat system, and almost every enemy is entirely unique in sprite and animation. There are numerous mini bosses, a large stable of end-stage bosses, and a ton of beautifully rendered stages to run around in, each of which are huge, sprawling, and give you the 'freedom' to zoom around in almost any direction.

The story has a very weird saturday-morning-but-adult vibe, with brightly colored characters and voice acting work that feels almost purposefully over the top and ham-y. It's a bit surprising how dark the story gets while maintaining a relatively child-like atmosphere. Some of the cutscenes do drag on, but there's an option to run the game sans cutscenes if all you want is to have fun and run the game again for time or simply just don't care about a story at all.

There are a lot of nice, professional polish touches to Freedom Planet. Many Bosses have cutscenes, but if you die you simply respawn a bit further back, and whne you approach the Boss they leap right into the combat without having to redo dialogue again.There are a ton of secrets, and everything is bright and well animated in lots of primary colors.  The game's pacing is frantic, but in a way that feels fun rather than rushed. Every level feels different in a good way, with new mechanics added almost before you've learned the last stage's unique playability.

It does have some problems though. Some might find the deviant-art-esque characters unappealing from an aesthetics point, and the dialogue can sometimes be cringeworthy. And certain environmental effects are instant-kills, which can be tempo-ruining, pulling you out of the game. However, these are all minor concerns in what is a surprising gem of a game that should please any of thsoe nostalgic for a game that plays start to finish with a satisfying saturday-morning-cartoon power of friendship storyline.

reviewText:
Freedom Planet - the moment I stepped into this game, I thought that it looked like a Sonic game, and according to the thousand-something other reviewers, I'm not alone. Avoiding the temptation of calling it a Sonic analog, what is Freedom Planet?

Freedom Planet is a 2d platformer with emphasis on speed and combat. Every girl is capable of going blindingly fast, so much that it can be hard to keep up with them; they can use this speed to climb up walls, outrun enemies, and soar up to otherwise hard-to-reach areas. There's no RPG element - the characters have all the powers needed to clear the game from the moment you pick them.

The protagonists each have their own little quirks that come out in the game's many cutscenes. Those that do not like the voice acting will be pleased to know that every cutscene can be skipped - those who do like cutscenes will find a pleasantly colorful story. Opinions will vary as to whether or not the writing is good, though it is the likeable characters which help pull everything together. For a game that is trying to keep its rating child-friendly, the villain is also surprisingly brutal; where some villains are content to yell I'll get you next time!" as the hero thwarts them
date: Lord Brevon acts as more of the "I don't think you really -need- to breathe right now" sort of antagonist.\n\nOne of the best aspects of the game would have to be the astoundingly well done sound track. Moody tracks play during tense combat-heavy levels
recommended: whereas up-beat or thrilling songs play during faster levels. Many of these tracks are great to listen to even outside the game
hoursPlayed: ranging between atmospheric and electronica for a nice diverse blend of background music. With 3 hours with of very well done music
voteText: the soundtrack is worthy of consideration.\n\nLevels are well done and fun to go through. If one is more of an explorer
helpfulPercent: there are hidden nooks and crannies everywhere hiding little hidden power ups
votesHelpful: crystals
votesTotal: and 'cards' that unlock sound files and concept art. If a person is the sort who prefers fast paced action
votesFunny: 'feeling' the level as they go
commentsCount: many of the levels challenge players to plow through them as fast as possible for the best time. Both the adrenaline junkie and the completionist will likely find a home in this game thanks to its wide yet free flowing design.\n\nAny criticism I have on the game is mostly nitpicking. I would have liked a proper borderless fullscreen mode [Edit: ten hours in

column18: and more importantly the ability to access the options menu while playing.\n\nI suppose I could also criticize the game's length

column20: and of course a possible second or third playthrough with different characters
column21: it still feels like we're only scratching the surface of what the world of Avalice has to offer. Heck
column22: I'm itching for a sequel already
column23: and this game has free DLC that has yet to be released.\n\nFreedom Planet is what an indie game -should- look like. Exciting

reviewText:
As a Sega kid I can definitely say I have a bit of bias whenever it comes to sonic-like platformers. I tend to judge them too harshly, or as rip offs. This platformer is actually.... very good. Why is it very good? Because it's passionate. These creators didn't just make this game to sell or to be famous, they LIKED making it and it's apparent in every detail from the fluent controls, the entrancing backgrounds and interactables to the amazing soundtrack. Let's get to the breakdowns I guess -

Controls: The very essence of any platformer games, I judge this part the most harshly in any platformer game I play but here, well... The game controls great. There was never a time where I was frustrated from the controls, if you screw up, it's all on you, not because of input lag, or movement delays, feels like it should feel, like you're in control. Took me a while to get used to it too, since the characters don't control exactly how you would think they do. I enjoyed the fact that walking on walls is actually a thing, adds a whole new level of openness and exploration to the levels which I enjoyed greatly and it's done cleverly enough that you don't abuse it at every chance.

Visuals: I can't even begin to describe how much effort was put into the visual design of each level, there's so much going on, but at the same time it's not TOO much that it's distracting. The sprites themselves are very well made and reflect the characters well enough. I would add a few more animations here and there for certain things, but all in all all of the enemies and characters are very well portrayed through visual means. The backgrounds are awesome, it's not just one big block that sticks in the background the whole time, no, they change with altitude and position and that's some thing I love. A lot of care was put into them and it shows.

Sounds and Music: I love the soundtrack. There's not much more to say, it has its own style, it varies from level to level and even within the same level, keeping your ears satisfied for the experience.

Voice Acting: Never thought I'd need to put this for a platformer... The weak part of the game, I'm afraid, is the voice acting... My favorites really are Carol and Torque, Brevon gives a good effort too but still... Lilac, Magister, Milla, Neera.... I wasn't expecting professional voice acting, and it's not like the voices are bad or unclear... just that they're too much? I dunno, it feels odd to say that about cartoony characters but they don't feel like they belong. Magister especially with his deep narrator voice doesn't feel genuine on any level. I think a lot of the voice acting would be better if they were trying a little more underplay. Its usually loud and in your face, especially in the more emotional scenes. Its not bad enough to detract from the experience, but it makes you roll your eyes, at least it made me.

Story: Not much to it, simple and to the point, predictable and linear. I think that's a good thing, keeps the atmosphere flowing and the action going.

Characters: I like them, they're each unique to play and control, each has their own abilities and movesets that diffrentiate their gameplay style a lot. Playing with Carol and her bike and Lilac are two different experiences entirely. Characters are portrayed pretty simplistically and not much is given about their background, which is a shame. I'd have hoped at least there'd be some bio for them. All we really know about the protagonists is that Carol and Lilac were part of a criminal group known as the Red Scarves, who were thieves led by Spade and that Lilac is a dragon. What happened to their parents? Where are they now? Why did they break off from the group? Not really explained. Otherwise each character's look and feel is unique and I like that.

Extra Content: Collectibles of music, art and voices, not very interesting really. Aside from Adventure mode there's also another arcade sort of mode- no story, just playing. You can also unlock playing as Milla which is nice. Although I would have liked seeing the ability to play as other characters as well. Achievements aren't too complicated to get, providing that you have the time for it.

All in all it's a great game for old school sonic fans. I think this kind of platformer is a good example for today's capabilities and can hold attention very well. It's fun, flowing, quick, intense, everything you need in a good platformer. The platformer it most reminds me of, ironically is actually Megaman Zero \ZX with its different movesets, abilities, the incorporation of speed and exploration as well as story and cutscenes. To the creators - very well done. I think Sega can learn a few lessons from you about how to make a new sonic 2D platformer game. I really enjoyed it.

reviewText:
There is no reason to play classic Sonic anymore. This is it. This is the game changer. This is a love letter to all the retro Saturn and Genesis fans.

Every playable character in this game is unique and has their own way of approaching each situation in a very smart way. The momentum never feels stale and the design is beautiful. If you don't have nostalgia for the era it probably won't grab you as much but it will still be appreciated. There's one stage that has a piano that you can step on - which ahs been done before in the Adnvace series I think but it's still nice to see it implemented into the game.

I thought the story was going to be bad and with tired cliches that you usually see in these kinds of games and although some of them are present the overall story is surprisingly deep. The cutscenes are too long which I think a lot of people complain about. There seems to be a lot of filler and a lot of things could be told differently or cut out of the game all together, I'm glad it's there though, it was engaging and interesting.. and with the classic mode I can just play stage by stage while still retaining knowledge of what is happening. I feel like the adventure mode is a one time playthrough for me, to put everything into perspective. The real seller is the gameplay, and it does that very well.

I definitely recommend this game! If you like platformers there's no reason that this shouldn't be in your library. It's a lot of fun and I'm glad it's here

reviewText:
Okay, I have played a lot more of the game now. All I can say is, wow, this has to be one of the greatest games I have ever played. It's like at my 3rd or 2nd all time favorite, and I'm debating whether I like this more than Mega Man X or not. And also, yes, this game is better than Sonic the Hedgehog in every aspect. Onto the review:

-Graphics/Art: Probably some of the best spritework I've seen in a long time. It looks colorful, bright, and very fun. I also happen to think that the main characters Lilac, Carol, and (unlockable) Milla happen to look adorable to be quite honest.

-Story: This isn't really the strongest point of the game, it's no Deus Ex-level storywriting. But it seems to be put together well enough where it's NOT cringe-worthy like your average Sonic game's story today. But the strongest point in the story-area is the characters, who happen to be quite well rounded and fun. For example: Lilac seems to be caring of others and determined to help them, even though she can have anger issues.

-Gameplay: The thing you should be looking forwards to in this game by far. It has plenty of game modes and character variety for you to replay, as well many achievements to try and unlock. Also, have I mentioned that this game is FREAKING DIFFICULT? It's not Kaizo-level difficult, but more rationally difficult. And also, the bosses can be hard to fight. Especially with Brevon, Spade, and Serpentine it's hard. The enemies seem to have a good enough variety to push you over once you think you know how to stop all of the enemies.

-Optimization: This game doesn't need the greatest PC to handle. Maybe a good monitor would make it better, but even when playing on a crappy 1152x648 monitor from CVS it looks great. So if you don't have the specs to play many 3D games, buy this!

Overall, this game deserves my rating of 93%. Buy it!

reviewText: I love this game from the bottom of my heart. It brings back the feeling of amazement I once had playing Sonic the first first. I still remember sitting down with my first Sega game and listening to the crisp music, abosrbing those vibrant colors and beautifully designed levels. Moving so fast you got a true sense of motion Sonic really launched you into a whole new world that Mario never really touched upon. Freedom Planet has this same sense of wonder for me, the graphics are beautiful the controls perfect and the music and sound a delight for the ears. It is as if an A + developer made a new game for the Sega after all these years and put all their talent and heart into the creation. I cannot recommend this game enough, if you have any fond memories of Sega games or old pixel games in general you will not be disappointed.\n\nThat being said ths is NOT Sonic, your character cannot jump on the heads of the enemies instead you have to attack them with a button press, in a way it combines the fast pace platforming of Sonic with the perfectly timed attacks of Ninja Gaiden. Your charactrs have a large number of moves to help you get around and find hidden locations and they're so adorable! Stop reading this and buy the freaking game already!
