reviewText:
This game is 100% nostalgia... And it feels so good! It might look like a Sonic rip-off, but don't judge a book by its cover... It WAS born as a Sonic fanmade game, but along the way it found its own identity and its own gameplay: it's slower, giving you the chance to explore the levels and to fight the enemies rather than rushing and trampling them.

The gaming experience is very well balanced, mixing platform-combat-exploration with the right pace, even giving you three characters with different sets of abilities and ways to approach a level .

The graphics are beautiful and the music... Oh man, how I missed this kind of tunes! Freedom Planet is a sweet ride to the golden age of 90s games.

The only bad thing I found it's the adventure mode... It DOES feel like a bad Sonic fanfiction, the dialogues are poorly written and there are many plot holes and inconguencies... But whatever, it was enjoyable at least. Still, it's better when you just play the levels and enjoy them

reviewText: This is a story about a small studio that decided they could make a better classic Sonic-like game than Sega, and launched a kickstarter for it. And I dare say, they succeeded at doing just that. Freedom planet is a glorious return to the Genesis era of 2D platformers that takes inspiration from Sonic the Hedgehog, Rocket Knight Adventure and their peers, wraps it all in a polished package, and adds good storytelling and voice-acting on top of all of it.\n\nThe only hitch in the mix is that the boss fights are unforgivingly hard, so newcomers to the genre should set the difficulty to Easy if they do not wish to experience the brutal difficulty of late 80s - early-90s gaming.

reviewText:
Ill get it out of the way, this game is very “Sonic” In character design and level design. That’s where the similarities end though, Freedom Planet is a very different beast and really deserves to be judged on its own merits. Freedom Planet is more a action game then a speedy platformer. Sure there are parts where you will be booking it through loop-de-loops but it blends combat in with it seamlessly and the levels lend themselves well to it. See most enemies don’t hurt you on contact, so you have two options. Blaze through the level and hit the occasional enemy on the way or stick around and fight it out. Both options are fine and both have there rewards and the game gives you everything you need to do it.

From the offset the game has three characters to play and all of them play drastically different. There’s Lilac who is more well rounded and great for first time players, Carol who can really kick ♥♥♥ with skillful play and Milla who is meant to be played slowly and more carefully and is really built for exploring the levels and finding shiny things. All of these characters are viable in all the different levels and they even each have there own levels unique to them. Each character is like playing a different game and most of the levels are balanced so every character has there own way of getting around them. There are even areas that only certain characters can access. It can be very difficult to build levels with multiple characters in mind and they have done a great job of it.

I will say some of the bosses can take a while to really get a bead on however the game pretty much lets you try again as much as you want until you finally get it right and that moment when you do can really be satisfying. The game does use a lives system but with how the continues work its really just kind of window dressing which is a bit of a oversight but it didn’t bother me too much. Though that makes going for the games main collectible Crystals kind of moot since all it really does is give you lives unless you care about high scores or bragging rights. I do really wish they could have reworked it cause the idea of doing away with lives period wouldn’t hurt me in the slightest. The reason I stuck with it til the end was because I DIDN’T have to start a level over, I actually had a chance to learn instead of drop the game out of frustration. Lives are a product of the times, when the games were all about eating quarters. I feel like lives are a outdated relic of the past and its just not good game design anymore, hardcore gamers be damned, but really its just a small nitpick on a otherwise great game.

I do want to end on a positive note though. I’m proud this game opted to have not one, not two but THREE female protagonists who are fun and interesting. I will say that while the story itself is pretty good its not super spectacular, But I do like how you get different pieces of the story depending on who you play and it does add good replay value. The characters are what really saved it for me. The writing is fun and the voice acting is also well done for having a lot of unknown actors. Having three female protagonists is really a breath of fresh air in a game industry ruled by scruffy white guys.

I highly recommend Freedom Planet especially if you’ve been craving a Sonic styled platformer like the good old days that feels like a long lost Saturn game. They plan on adding more content for free later including 2 new characters with there own parts of the story to play which frankly im very excited for. Give this game a look.

reviewText:
One of the best games I played in a while. This is definitely a hidden gem. It makes me sad that nobody knows that this game exists. Thank goodness my friend told me about this game because when I saw it, I loved it instantly. Here's why this game is SEVERELY UNDERRATED:

POSITIVES:
- Interesting, addicting, and unique gameplay inspired by the classics. A Sonic-like feel to it, but with a mixture of more action.
- MUSIC IS--HOLY SMOKES GOD-TIER AMAZING!
- Three characters to play as, each with unique traits to use during the game. Each character's gameplay is refreshing and different!
- Story is surprisngly good and engaging. Fleshes out characters and makes you have feelings toward them during their struggle to defeat Lord Brevon.
- Voice acting is surprisingly good!
- Levels are creative and well-paced. Each level has features that the characters can take advantage of.
- ACHIEVEMENTS!
- Able to play the story mode in two different perspectives by picking either Lilac or Carol
- Encourages player to explore or speed-run through the stages!
- Boss fights are amazing
- Game presents a challenge as you go through higher levels
- Future content is planned! We'll be continuously adding new features
date:
and any future DLC we include will be free of charge"

NEGATIVES:

I really can't think of any more negatives. The game is that good. I would even say that this game is better than Sonic 3 and Knuckles and I'm a Sonic fan. What an experience this game was. Do yourself a favor! Play this game and see for yourself! Hell

reviewText:
This is one of my favorite indie games of all time, for a variety of reasons. There are a few flaws, but the strengths of the game far outweigh them.

Pros
GAMEPLAY. This game lets you do what you please. Want to speedrun a course? Go ahead. Want to take time to explore and collect cards and crystals? Knock yourself out. Feel like beating up a bunch of robots or fighting 99 ninjas head on? Yup, you can do that too. Anything. Not only is there an Adventure mode with fully voiced cutscenes and fun story, but you can play in Classic mode and there are time trials as well. Along with achievements, there's a ton of unique gameplay waiting for you in this game.
LENGTH. I got this game for half price, and I can definitely say it was 200% worth it. I've already poured 60 hours into it and I've just completed Adventure mode with only one of the characters. Yeah, there's a lot of content packed in here.
CHARACTERS. These characters are so much fun. You can play as Lilac, a dragon, Carol, a wildcat, or Milla, a basset hound, each with their own unique powers and weaknesses. They're beautifully designed and a lot of love went into making them.
MUSIC. Freedom Planet's OST is on par with the likes of Shovel Knight. It's that good. In fact, the Shovel Knight OST and the Freedom Planet OST are my top two video game soundtracks of 2014.
VOICE ACTORS. Now, a lot of people are complaining about the amateur voice actors and their cheesy lines, but I actually really liked the voice acting as well as the animated cutscenes. It added a lot of polish to the game, and if you don't care for story, you can always play in Classic mode. But the voice actors made the game feel complete, and I especially want to credit Spade, Torque, Carol, and Lord Brevon for having great, almost professional voice acting.
STORY. This shiz got dark real quick at the beginning, when  Lord Brevon beheaded the King of Shuigang in front of his son But after that it was pretty lighthearted  and it made me laugh and want to know more. The plot, although interesting, is nothing new. Still, its got a nice vibe to it, and I found the story pleasant but also significant. Reminded me a lot of Sonic SatAM if that rings a bell.
Now for the Cons. I really only have one big one:
DIFFICULTY. Nuts this game was hard. Really hard. I played on Normal until I reached the Dreadnoughts. Then I dropped to Easy. Then I reached the final Dreanought and dropped to Casual (I have failed as a gamer). While I found the difficulty pretty fair until the Dreadnoughts, I think the game could do with a slight tone down. If you like a challenge, then by all means have a blast. But I did not like having to lower my difficulty just so I could get past a stage.
MALE CHARACTERS. This is a small one that will (hopefully!) be fixed with upcoming DLC. As much as I love girls in gaming, I would've loved to play as one of the male characters, like Torque or Spade. My brother (who also played this game with me) wholeheartedly agrees.
BUGS. Some minor bugs, but no gamebreakers. Sometimes I'll just fall through the floor and have to restart, but it rarely happens and it's no big deal.
WHAT ARE YOU DOING READING THIS LONG AWFUL REVIEW. GO BUY THIS GAME.

reviewText:
Cons:
-Some late game bugs
-Levels can be a bit long

Pros:
-Great Story
-Strong Female Characters (if your into that)
-Tight Controls
-Colorful artstyle
-Great variety of moves for different characters (does not feel like re-skins)

A lot of people can point at this game and obviously point out that this looks like a Sonic clone, however I think this game surpasses Classic Sonic in nearly every detail. Unlike Classic Sonic games, this game has in game cutscenes (comprised of sprites), and voice acting. This game seems to be a real fusion of the classic 2d runner formula and the inovation we've seen in 2d platforms long since the age of the NES. The gameplay is fluid and I never experienced any framerate issues, altthough some late game bugs hampered my gameplay for about 20 seconds before I went right back to normal gameplay. The levels are varied, although they can be a bit long, with one level nearly taking me 12 minutes. This game is well worth the money, and I prefer this to any Sonic game anyday.

reviewText:
Review of Freedom Planet
Freedom Planet instantly became one of my favorites. The visuals and the way it plays remind me of the old Sonic games (e.g. Sonic 3 & Knuckles). Even though the voice acting has its issues I found that it really contributes to the characters' personalities - I simply fell in love with them. The game also offers a pretty entertaining story mode (Called Adventure Mode) as well as a Classic mode (Which skips all of the cutscenes)

Cons:
-The voice acting is nice but it's not levelled properly (e.g. one character is voiced normally and the next is too loud)...

Pros:
-Awesome retro visuals and gameplay.
-The game is voice acted!
-Lenghty (skippable) cutscenes between the stages. It's almost like watching a movie.
-3 playable and lovable characters.

Conclusion:
All in all, Freedom Planet is very similar to the retro Sonic games - pleasant visuals, pleasant gameplay and pleasant music but it also offers some upgrades" that the Sonic games don't have - It has voice acted cutscenes which allow you to get immeresed into the story. If you're wondering whether the game is worth the money - it is! :)"

reviewText:
If you like old school games, play this.
If you like platformers, play this.
If you like Sonic games, play this and realise this is the closest thing there's been to a Sonic game in ages.

The game is expertly crafted and feels like a game straight out of the 16 bit era. The visuals are excellent, the art design for the characters and levels are all very inspiring, and the gameplay is extremely tight. I really dont think that there's anything negative to say here. I just know this is essentially the Sonic game I've been waiting years and years for. I genuinely hope there will be sequels, as this is a franchise that could have lots and lots of potential!

EDIT: I'd like to made one amendment to my review. Upon completion of the game I have one more gripe to add. The later bosses of the game start to have an extreme difficulty spike, and part of this is due to how the bosses are paced. Some of the bosses start to resemble bullet hell games, and rarely back off of the pacing. Some of the end bosses can be frustratingly difficult, especially when measured against the difficulty of the levels themselves.

Original Score: 9/10
Amended Score: 8/10

reviewText:
GalaxyTrail appear to have access to some sort of time machine, or perhaps can freely traverse parallel universes at-will. It's the only way to explain a game which seems to have come from a universe where Sega released a Sonic 4 for the Sega Saturn and the franchise never suffered its fall from grace after Sonic 3 & Knuckles.

Despite that comparison, Freedom Planet is very much its own game and not some Sonic clone, however strong it may have been influenced by the Blue Blur. You'll find a game which is to the late Sega Megadrive era what Shovel Knight is the NES, and like Shovel Knight it takes inspiration from multiple classics. You may find elements of Rocket Knight Adventures, Mega Man X, Ristar and Gunstar Heroes blending into the mix and its wonderful.

The presentation of the story (yes, somebody put plot in my 90s platformer) is odd for a platformer of this type, featuring sometimes lengthy in-game cutscenes and full, somewhat-cheesy voice acting. It seems somewhat reminiscent of some of the Sonic spinoff media like the comics and won't win any awards but helps add a little more life to the game.
If you really can't stand the dialogue or want a more traditional experience, the Classic mode should satisfy you, and even in Adventure scenes can be easily skipped.

There's more to Freedom Planet than just appealing to nostalgia and, like Shovel Knight, it very much stands up on its own merits. There's speed, sure, but there's a greater emphasis on platforming, on sometimes slowing down to deal with enemies and occasionally go vaguely metroidvania with exploration and puzzles for short segments.
That may not sound that great if you're looking for a classic Sonic experience, but it works well here and helps further distance the game from its main inspiration, which sometimes focused too heavily on speed.

With plenty of achievements, 3 characters for Classic mode (with more to come?). Time Attack, multiple difficulties and some fair challenge, there's plenty to experience. What can I say? If you grew up with this sort of game, you probably want this. If you loved Shovel Knight, you might dig this. If you're a long-time Sonic fan looking fondly at your old cartridges, you owe it to yourself to give this game a chance.

With a free demo, what do you have to lose?

If you’ve been looking for a good “old” platformer in the best sense of the word but always felt disappointed by the recent Sonic releases, look no further but treat yourself to this great title!\n\nFull review: http://metadragon.de/game-review/review-freedom-planet/

reviewText:
I was going to call this a homage to classic platformers, but I think Freedom Planet deserves better. From it's humble start as a Sonic fan-game I followed it's development as it evolved into a bigger and better game. Even in it's early days I saw it's potential, and to think that it's done nothing but improve since the initial demos! It has moved well beyond it's origins now. It's less a of tribute and more of an evolution of a classic formula.

Yes, the movement is very Sonic-esque. However, a key difference is the combat system. Freedom Planet uses a traditional health bar as opposed to rings. Where Sonic relies on passive attacks with jumps or spindashes, Freedom Planet has active attacks with a full suite of moves that you will need to master to survive the later levels. This is a crucial point of difference that radically changes the way the game plays. These moves integrate into the platforming very well which makes for flashy, fluid gameplay. It's very satisfying once you get the hang of it.

The varied levels are generally fun to explore, full of color and backed by great music. I found myself playing slower than I would in Sonic just to admire the environments and see what I could find. There's also a lot more to interact with in each level, and while I wouldn't claim many are puzzles it makes the game more interesting and helps break up (or is pressured by) the combat. Enemies and bosses are diverse enough to provide new challenges from level to level.

If you are a fan of cheesy dialogue and voice acting the adventure mode is a joy to play. It reminds me of a good saturday morning cartoon, balancing light-hearted humor with serious developments. If you're not into that you can opt to ignore it entirely and play through the game with no cutscenes in classic mode. The story does provide context to the levels, of course, so they are at least somewhat necessary IMO. Note that one character (Milla) is exclusive to classic mode: only Lilac and Carol are playable in adventure mode.

The difficulty quickly ramps up midway through with certain bosses rivaling Dark Souls near the end. Many enemies and level hazards are also tough to deal with if unprepared. It's up to you to learn their attacks and hone your skills as there's no stat progression to make it easier, only a very forgiving continue should you game over. Quick reflexes are necessary to make any sort of progress in the final stages where health is a luxury. It can be a nightmare to complete even on normal difficulty, but the feeling of accomplishment makes it all worth it once you finally manage to push through and win.

Freedom Planet earns a well deserved spot on my list of favorite games in recent memory. Anyone who dismisses it as a Sonic clone is simply missing out.

reviewText:
Gawd, where do I begin, ever since I was a kid, I LOVED the Sonic games for the Sega Genesis, and this game gave me a HUGE nostalgia trip. Aside from that, the gameplay felt refreshing from your typical 2D platformer, and the music was just awesome; they even retained what they did in Sonic the Hedgehog 3, and changed the music for the 2nd act of the level.

The characters are adorable, extremely memorable, and sometimes you can really feel the direct connection between some of them (I don't remember the last time I absolutely despised a villain in a game, but the main antagonist is definitely someone I despise.) There are also three characters to choose from (third one is unlocked and currently has no story mode at the moment, just classic mode), with a fourth coming soon(?). If you're not one to really care for the story (Big mistake but whatever floats your boat) then you can just play in classic mode, so the stages just go in order.

Did I mention there's also Mahjong? (Albeit super easy.)

All in all, epic game, epic characters, and EPIC music. 10/10 Would recommend even at full price.

reviewText: When Sonic The Hedgehog came out, it was followed by a series of micking games that tried to capitalize on it's popularity. Games like Bubs the Bobcat and Aero the Acrobat were, for all intents and purposes, replicas of Sonic right down to the title of the game. Some were good and some were fairly derivative. Freedom Planet, much like those games, recaptures what we loved about the Sonic 2D platformers of the Genesis age, but it lies in the first category. With multiple characters to choose from, individual gameplay styles, fantastic production values, and an interesting story, Freedom Planet is a fun platformer that feels like a true homage to the Sonic series. If you were a Sonic fan, Freedom Planet is most definitely a must buy.

reviewText:
The game is very similar to the side scrolling sonic the hedgehog games in a lot of ways, your goal is to get from one end to the other, you can either go fast or beat up all the bad guys you come across its up to you.
The good points: the sonic fanbase has a sort of competition sort of thing to see who can get through the game the fastest, and this game adds to that meaning it does have a ton of replay value to try to beat your previous time
There are three choosable characters who do play differently to eachother which is a nice change  to the same character with a different skin
The game has a full story with voice acting, the story is reminicent of the sonic the hedgehog cartoon in the 90's where sonic and gang have to stop the evil robotnic with the sort of fun kid friendly 1990's cheesiness
The badguys are not completly stupid, yes some of them do just follow specific routes but a lot of them do actually try to dodge your attacks and to actually hit you rather than just shooting randomly
The kickass soundtrack

The bad points
if you dont like side scrolling platformers, you will not like this, it can be difficult to beat some bosses sometimes and whilst that may be what some people are looking for, I'm sure a few of you will be put off by this
Sometimes, in some levels there are badguys that fly past in the background shooting laser blasts and stuff, this can be sometimes distracting although I may just be really bad, but this only happens in a few levels so its not too bad

General notes
There is a life system, for some reason and you gain lives by collecting crystals, there isnt really any reason for this as if you get a game over you can start from the same check point
There is no multiplayer, this game screams it could do with multiplayer, wether its just a pvp race or a full on co-op, that could make this game so much better

Should you get this game, sure, why not

reviewText:
If you're a fan of classic platformers like Mega Man, Sonic the Hedgehog and Rocket Knight, you have NO REASON to not own this game. The levels are superbly designed, the bosses are intense and challenging, and it gives awesome incentive to be replayed multiple times as you have three different characters (four in the later future) that not only play entirely different from one another, but also have their own levels and branching paths!

The only thing that might turn you off is its plot-hole ridden and inconsistent story. It's fanfic material, escalating between lighthearted GIRL POWER kid-friendly stuff, to dark and serious territory involving politics, war and TORTURE. And keep in mind that the characters are a bunch of adorable, simple minded furries that want to save the world from an unstoppable evil. Its transition from kid friendly mindsets of saving the world, to the characters having realistic notions of stuff just doesn't work. I won't spoil anything, but the tale that Galaxy Trail made is filled with eye rolling cringe" moments and that's kinda disappointing. The story tries so hard to be mature for its own good.

But that doesn't stop Freedom Planet from being an excellent game. I'm not even a huge fan of old school platformers and I still adored every minute of it. Let that be a tip to any who are shy of the genre
date: because Freedom Planet does an excellent job balancing its mechanics by being both a 2D action game and an obstacle course platformer. You have the best of both worlds
recommended: and it never becomes a Jack-of-All trades kinda thing where it fails to achieve quality gameplay by doing too much; both aspects are next to flawless. Movement can be a little slippery and sensitive
hoursPlayed: and the physics are sort of wonky as of this moment

reviewText: This game is money well spent! It's a cornucopia of 90s goodness! It's SO 90s that it's practically like you're playing it on a Sega Geneis while drinking a Coke Classic at a juice bar run by Crash Bandicoot and Sonic the Hedgehog and staffed by the Road Rovers with Johnny Bravo on Next while the Mask is in the background hustling at a game of Pool with Homestar Runner and Sam & Max: Freelance Police is on TV...Yoshis. I do see a few similarities to the Blue Blur's haydays, so I can tell why SOME would peg it as a Clone, but I say NUTS to that crap! The game is WORLDS away from that guy, both figuratively and literally.\n\nThe game itself and its levels are like a bag of potato chips: You can't (b)eat just one! Case and point, I finally pulled myself away from it to write this review. If they made a sequel, I'd be all for it and waiting (I can't afford to support a kickstarter)! Not since My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic have I been so enthralled in something of this variety. In fact, I can safely say the main playable characters remind me a little of one half of the Mane Six (Sash Lilac = Twilight Sparkle, Carol Tea = Rainbow Dash and Milla Basset = Fluttershy). The only thing that I feel bad about is that it's likely going to be future Dorkly material. But that's okay, still a great game! So what are you waiting for? Download it and never mind the naysayers!

reviewText: If you buy this game, you buy it for the platforming, and you get a helluva experience.  I personally loved the fact that there was no tutorial, it made me fell like the game thought that holding my hand was a waste of time and let me loose.  All the mechanics are easy to understand and get a grasp of, although the game gets ball wrenchingly hard at times.\nThe best part of this game is the fact that it reminds me of old sonic games.  I personally never played them, but it feels nice that there's someone out there that understands this niche part and caters to them.  If there are any complaints its the fact that the pricetag may be too much for some people and the story is rather uninspired.  The story, but not the characters.  I find the characters to be rather well designed and voiced.  All in all its a really good game that platformer fans and sonic fans will enjoy.

reviewText:
Enormous levels, catchy music, cute character designs, gorgeous pixel art, perfectly matched level color palettes, forgiving difficulty curve, tons of rewards for exploring, the list of positives goes on.

The level of polish and detail in of each of the whopping [VERY MANY] levels and cutscenes speaks directly to the developer's love of 16/32-bit era platformers and of the Sonic franchise. It's not a Sonic clone but you can almost feel the sheer heart poured into this game to make it as faithful to this style of platformer as possible all while maintaining it's own identity and spirit.

This is Shovel Knight-levels of quality with nowhere near Shovel Knight-levels of attention. Let's change that!

reviewText:
This game is absolutely fantastic: the sprites are beautiful, the gameplay is excellent, and the music is porn for the ears.
However, this game is not for everyone. The plot, while having some lighthearted moments, is EXTREMELY dark, featuring decapitation and torture (multiple times, may I add!). The difficulty is also extraordinarily high, with the later levels being insanely harsh.

Also, a warning: This game's final boss will beat you to the ground. It will make you cry. It will kill you after you are already dead... seriously.
Overall, the game is an easy 9/10, albiet if you're easily enraged it's an 8/10.

reviewText:
One of the best games I played in a while. This is definitely a hidden gem. It makes me sad that nobody knows that this game exists. Thank goodness my friend told me about this game because when I saw it, I loved it instantly. Here's why this game is SEVERELY UNDERRATED:

reviewText:
Not a long review, simply amazing and BUY BUY BUY this game at full price now! I got it on sale, but it's a $20 game in my book and destroys the AAA $60 games of 2014 and even as of recent years.

I didn't grow up in the NES/NES era. But being a young kid in the late 90s and early 00s I played platformers all the time and this game brings you back to those simple times when it was just you and your 2D graphics with challenging platforming. This isn't just some casual indie game. You can tell the devs poured their souls into making this game as perfect as they could.

Pros

+Graphics are timeless and it feels like something on the PS1
+Sonic and Mega Man X gameplay fused perfectly, Lilac, Carol and Milla all are distinct from each other
+Soundtrack gets the blood flowing
+Sure you have unlimited lives, but achievement hunters will be challenged by not dying at all
+The story mode gets complaints, but for a side scroller, it works
+ You're playing a saturday morning cartoon, who doesn't want that?
+No cheap deaths or game breaking bugs
+I didn't hate one boss fight, all are awesome. yes, you will die from learning attack paterns. But these bosses of course can be beaten.. Git goood

cons

-I wish I did have lives, I know it's just for fun, but I want to be alarmed and on my foot like dying matters in a game

That's my only con, that the game has unlimited continues.


Buy this game, what the hell are you doing not buying it?!

reviewText: Wow, I was quickly getting bored with the games I had and when I purchased this gem it provided just the challenge that I have been longing for in a platformer without being super unfair. The art style is cutesy and seems very much like a Sonic the Hedgehog and Ristar hybrid gameplay wise with the perfect amount of originality tossed in to it (mostly in the form of the combat but in other ways too). The story is cool too and way more in depth than that you get when grabbing most sidescrollers and while some of the voices I wasn't too fond of I did enjoy the plot that was given to me and the characters got the points across in times of emotion. The combat system is fun and doesn't detract from the platforming, if anything it adds to it immensely and allows you lots of room to improvise with getting through an area. The bosses are a blast to try to beat, while difficult (each one taking myself several attempts to beat), they aren't overly unfair if you know how to work the abilities at your disposal. Overall I'd say it is certainly worth the buy, those who are fans of retro-esque platformers will likely love it since it takes everything from classic high speed platforming games and improves on it ten-fold.

reviewText:
Gawd, where do I begin, ever since I was a kid, I LOVED the Sonic games for the Sega Genesis, and this game gave me a HUGE nostalgia trip. Aside from that, the gameplay felt refreshing from your typical 2D platformer, and the music was just awesome; they even retained what they did in Sonic the Hedgehog 3, and changed the music for the 2nd act of the level.

The characters are adorable, extremely memorable, and sometimes you can really feel the direct connection between some of them (I don't remember the last time I absolutely despised a villain in a game, but the main antagonist is definitely someone I despise.) There are also three characters to choose from (third one is unlocked and currently has no story mode at the moment, just classic mode), with a fourth coming soon(?). If you're not one to really care for the story (Big mistake but whatever floats your boat) then you can just play in classic mode, so the stages just go in order.

Did I mention there's also Mahjong? (Albeit super easy.)

All in all, epic game, epic characters, and EPIC music. 10/10 Would recommend even at full price.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game brings out 2 emotions for me: Happiness and sadness.
Freedom Planet originally started development as a Sonic The Hedgehog fan title but over time it evolved into its own standalone title.

Visuals:
Vibrant and smooth. In todays gaming world of brown and gray it is nice to see a title that is awash with primary colours. Stages each have their own distinct theme and the colour choices fit them perfectly. The only thing I can liken it too is Dynamite Headdy or Ristar The Shooting Star on the Sega Megadrive (Genesis). If those games appealed to you and you like speed then this is the game for you.

Sound:
I only have, at the time of this review, 1.5 hours  on record so its not really enough time to judge accurately. However,  from what Ive heard so far it is great. Voice acting is a bit hit-and-miss at times but for a fan game its good. Each stage music fits the stage perfectly and has a very Saturn-esque vibe going on with both a mix of synth and CD-quality audio.

Story:
Again, as above, Im not far into the game but it is quite a light-hearted story with some occasional dark moments.

Gameplay:
The most important aspect and it delivers in spades. You take the role of 3 characters Lilac (dragon), Carol (cat, I think) and another I forgot the name of. Each have their own powerups and abilities to help navigate the expansive levels. Despite being heavily influenced by Sonic you dont have the standard collectible items that stop you dying in 1 hit" mechanic here. There are blue gems to collect with 200 netting you an extra life. You do however have a life bar which is replenished by collecting red leaf looking items. Above your health is what amounts to a mana bar that powers your secondary attacks. This refills over time and moves cannot be performed until it is refilled.
Perhaps the hardest thing to get to grips with is enemy behaviour. In most 2D sidescrollers simply touching an enemy results in a hit. Not here
date: the enemy has to be in an attack animation. Although a good idea in theory
recommended:
it can make enemy hitboxes seem a bit....off :/

Final Thoughts:
An underrated gem that fans of classic Sonic and classic platformers will enjoy. Story
hoursPlayed: from what Ive read
voteText: is a good 5-6 hours long. Characters are well fleshed out and the music is brilliant\n\n10/10 by a country mile"

reviewText:
The game is very similar to the side scrolling sonic the hedgehog games in a lot of ways, your goal is to get from one end to the other, you can either go fast or beat up all the bad guys you come across its up to you.
The good points: the sonic fanbase has a sort of competition sort of thing to see who can get through the game the fastest, and this game adds to that meaning it does have a ton of replay value to try to beat your previous time
There are three choosable characters who do play differently to eachother which is a nice change  to the same character with a different skin
The game has a full story with voice acting, the story is reminicent of the sonic the hedgehog cartoon in the 90's where sonic and gang have to stop the evil robotnic with the sort of fun kid friendly 1990's cheesiness
The badguys are not completly stupid, yes some of them do just follow specific routes but a lot of them do actually try to dodge your attacks and to actually hit you rather than just shooting randomly
The kickass soundtrack

The bad points
if you dont like side scrolling platformers, you will not like this, it can be difficult to beat some bosses sometimes and whilst that may be what some people are looking for, I'm sure a few of you will be put off by this
Sometimes, in some levels there are badguys that fly past in the background shooting laser blasts and stuff, this can be sometimes distracting although I may just be really bad, but this only happens in a few levels so its not too bad

General notes
There is a life system, for some reason and you gain lives by collecting crystals, there isnt really any reason for this as if you get a game over you can start from the same check point
There is no multiplayer, this game screams it could do with multiplayer, wether its just a pvp race or a full on co-op, that could make this game so much better

Should you get this game, sure, why not

reviewText:
Having played the original Sonic the Hedgehog games for probably a decade, Freedom Planet was a must-buy when I saw the trailer. I can safely say it did not disappoint.

This game is clearly influenced from popular games from the 90's, but still manages to feel original. The 3 main characters all play differently, keeping the game feeling fresh and giving it replay value (I've spent 8 hours with 1 character). The game still has some glitches, but the developer is actively working to fix them.

Freedom Planet also gave me a strong sense of satisfaction. This game is not easy, and the bosses are even harder, but the feeling you get when you get that last hit makes up for it.

I highly recommend Freedom Planet to just about anybody who has $15 to spend on something awesome.

9/10

reviewText: This is an amazing game.\nFirst of all, Freedom Planet is a pleasure to the senses. The music and visual design marry to form an incredibly charming world. The foreground objects and background scenery are varied and feel alive with energy, from the natural out door areas through to the constructed, synthetic final areas. The character designs, even the tertiary and background characters, are appealing and feel like a good fit" to the world they inhabit. The voice acting isn't flawless
date: but even that works out in Freedom Planet's favor
recommended: adding a "Saturday Morning Cartoon" charm to the dialogue.\nI was personally very impressed with the way that the main characters are depicted; games featuring a strong female lead generally tend to over-emphiasize the hero's femininity or completely ignore it. There is also a tendency to make female heroes either too strong
hoursPlayed: or too weak
voteText: in comparison to their male counterparts. Freedom Planet pretty cleanly evades this entire hail of metaphorical bullets with Lilac and Carol. Though Carol is intended to be the more tomboy-ish of the pair
helpfulPercent: both manage to show us their strength and their weakness without ever needing to stop and remind the audience
votesHelpful: "Oh
votesTotal: by the way
votesFunny: I'm female
commentsCount: as though it's an excuse.\nWhile decidedly not a clone or a spin-off, Freedom Planet's roots as a Sonic the Hedgehog derived work show themselves in the level designs; expect to see ramps, looping circular paths, springs, switches, and other set peices normally unique to SEGA's 2D flagship series. As such, a number of them end up feeling out of place or clumsy (springs, in particular, cause Lilac to skid to an agonizing halt due to the momentum-handling). In general, the level layouts are probably the game's biggest shortcoming. Lilac and Carol (and later Mila) share stages, meaning that it needs to be possible for both characters (possessing radically different modes of movement) to complete said areas. Carol's motorcycle climbing ladders aside, Lilac's special action tends to send her face-planting against walls intended for Carol to climb at least a few times each level.\nThe game's difficulty can also be frustrating; many, many parts of the game feel as though they're just right
column16: causing some of the boss fights to be impossibly hard by comparison. Lilac in particular will have a hard time finding ways to hit some of her bosses, as her normal attacks have too little reach to avoid damage, and her dash drains her entire special action meter when used. Most of the length of the bosses was spent waiting for the dragon dash to recharge. Carol faces similar problems on one boss in particular, where her wild kick needs to be managed carefully.\nThe last two paragraphs are definitely minor complaints surrounding what is possibly one of the most amazing games I've ever played. The entire experience gave my inner child an ear-to-ear smile. Pass this one up only if you absolutely don't like things that are fun.

reviewText:
How to put a description of Freedom Planet into words...

Freedom Planet is honestly one of the best games that I've bought and played in a while.
The game mixes platforming and combat perfectly to a point of perfection.
The difficulty curve is very smooth as the levels and bosses become harder at a nice and slow pace, yet not too slow.
The only complaint that i have for the game is that a few of the bosses have a difficulty spike that it takes quite a few deaths to finally beat them, but the feeling you get after beating them is rewarding and makes the difficulty spike not all that bad.

I'd give Freedom Planet a 9.5 out of 10 and I'm really looking forward to the addition of Milla's story, and the Spade and Torque playable characters and their story's.

reviewText: I don't care if you're a casual gamer, a hard core gamer, an FPS fan, a kawaii gamer, or game hater, you MUST, absolutely MUST play this game. The characters are colourful (not just literally) loveable, and given amazing voice actors, the story is intriguing, the kind that haunts you to find out what happens, there's unique and extremely challenging boss fights, (although you can use Carol's motorcycle to cheat quite a few of them) fun gameplay, great music, awesome 16-bit visuals, adorable power-up creatures, hilarious easter eggs, and so much more! reviewText: While not as fresh as something like Shovel Knight the fact is that this game should not be labeled as a Sonic Knock off and dismissed entirely. Yes, this game did start of as a sonic hack before turning into it's own game and Lilac was originally designed as a hedgehog but this game is still a fun time with well designed levels which aren't specialised for any specific character and I can't even do the soundtrack justice with my words but all I will say is that it is amazing! reviewText:
If you're a fan of classic platformers like Mega Man, Sonic the Hedgehog and Rocket Knight, you have NO REASON to not own this game. The levels are superbly designed, the bosses are intense and challenging, and it gives awesome incentive to be replayed multiple times as you have three different characters (four in the later future) that not only play entirely different from one another, but also have their own levels and branching paths!

The only thing that might turn you off is its plot-hole ridden and inconsistent story. It's fanfic material, escalating between lighthearted GIRL POWER kid-friendly stuff, to dark and serious territory involving politics, war and TORTURE. And keep in mind that the characters are a bunch of adorable, simple minded furries that want to save the world from an unstoppable evil. Its transition from kid friendly mindsets of saving the world, to the characters having realistic notions of stuff just doesn't work. I won't spoil anything, but the tale that Galaxy Trail made is filled with eye rolling cringe" moments and that's kinda disappointing. The story tries so hard to be mature for its own good.

But that doesn't stop Freedom Planet from being an excellent game. I'm not even a huge fan of old school platformers and I still adored every minute of it. Let that be a tip to any who are shy of the genre
date: because Freedom Planet does an excellent job balancing its mechanics by being both a 2D action game and an obstacle course platformer. You have the best of both worlds
recommended: and it never becomes a Jack-of-All trades kinda thing where it fails to achieve quality gameplay by doing too much; both aspects are next to flawless. Movement can be a little slippery and sensitive

reviewText:
Overall: Recommended for most, but some annoyances may distract from the experience.

Freedom Planet captures the oldschool platformer feel. Freedom Planet is to Sonic what Shovel Knight is to Mega Man.If you enjoy old school platformers, then there shouldn't be any reason for you to not like Freedom Planet... for the most part.

The good

The level design is great, and despite the relatively open levels, I never felt lost as one could easily become in this kind of sonic-like platformer. Gameplay elements change stage to stage, and are always properly introduced.
The music is great, and on par with oldschool classics. I highly value the quality of music in games, and this has received plenty of attention in Freedom Planet.
Gameplay is solid, and has a natural difficulty curve. The levels themselves always feels just right in terms of difficulty.
The pixel art for this game is absolutely gorgeous at times. The character design is also very well done.
The bad
The controls are not particularly tight due to the high standard controller sensitivity. I recommend reducing it to 50% as leaving it at 100% can interfere with gameplay, not to mention make menu navigation a nightmare.
The story is rather dull and uninteresting, and the overall plot feels rushed.
What doesn't help the story is the often terrible voice acting. This didn't exactly help my opinion on the story, as I found myself skipping through dialogue to avoid hearing it. With no menu option to turn off voices, this was a constant annoyance that broke immersion for me throughout the entire game. The bad voice acting itself made me question giving this game a positive review, but I feel that other factors outweigh this issue.
The game is hard. Reel hard. This is definitely on par with standard NES/SNES era platformers, but that's fine. The problem comes with later bosses (especially the final boss) feeling artificially difficult to the point where I was on the brink of rage quitting; two thirds of my deaths were on two bosses alone. If not for the generous save system I would not have been able to finish the game.
It takes only about five to six hours to complete the game, and while the game has replay value in terms of multiple characters and modes, collectables and achievements, I didn't personally feel any desire to replay this particular game. Others may feel differently on this issue.

reviewText:
This game is what you'd get if you took WayForward back in time to the mid 90's to make a game with Treasure, 90's Era Sonic Team, and the people who did Rocket Knight Adventures. It is the best parts of all of them, and it is GLORIOUS.

A friend of mine put it thus:
If Shovel Knight is a love letter to the NES, then Freedom Planet is a love letter to the Genesis.

And the reaction I had from the trailers was 'It's as if Treasure, Wayforward, and 90's era Sonic Team had a baby'

The voice acting is a little bit uneven - mainly in the disparate recording setups, but being an indie game, is at least somewhat expected.
Later stages can get kinda difficult, and there's no health regen between stages in Adventure mode.

This review has been written before finishing with one character (Lilac), but I expect nothing to change.

If you like the 16 bit era of gaming, you owe it to yourself to buy this. Simple as that.

reviewText:
Having played the original Sonic the Hedgehog games for probably a decade, Freedom Planet was a must-buy when I saw the trailer. I can safely say it did not disappoint.

This game is clearly influenced from popular games from the 90's, but still manages to feel original. The 3 main characters all play differently, keeping the game feeling fresh and giving it replay value (I've spent 8 hours with 1 character). The game still has some glitches, but the developer is actively working to fix them.

Freedom Planet also gave me a strong sense of satisfaction. This game is not easy, and the bosses are even harder, but the feeling you get when you get that last hit makes up for it.

I highly recommend Freedom Planet to just about anybody who has $15 to spend on something awesome.

9/10

reviewText: This is an amazing game.\nFirst of all, Freedom Planet is a pleasure to the senses. The music and visual design marry to form an incredibly charming world. The foreground objects and background scenery are varied and feel alive with energy, from the natural out door areas through to the constructed, synthetic final areas. The character designs, even the tertiary and background characters, are appealing and feel like a good fit" to the world they inhabit. The voice acting isn't flawless

There is also a tendency to make female heroes either too strong
hoursPlayed: or too weak
voteText: in comparison to their male counterparts. Freedom Planet pretty cleanly evades this entire hail of metaphorical bullets with Lilac and Carol. Though Carol is intended to be the more tomboy-ish of the pair
helpfulPercent: both manage to show us their strength and their weakness without ever needing to stop and remind the audience
votesHelpful: "Oh
votesTotal: by the way
votesFunny: I'm female
commentsCount: as though it's an excuse.\nWhile decidedly not a clone or a spin-off, Freedom Planet's roots as a Sonic the Hedgehog derived work show themselves in the level designs; expect to see ramps, looping circular paths, springs, switches, and other set peices normally unique to SEGA's 2D flagship series. As such, a number of them end up feeling out of place or clumsy (springs, in particular, cause Lilac to skid to an agonizing halt due to the momentum-handling). In general, the level layouts are probably the game's biggest shortcoming. Lilac and Carol (and later Mila) share stages, meaning that it needs to be possible for both characters (possessing radically different modes of movement) to complete said areas. Carol's motorcycle climbing ladders aside, Lilac's special action tends to send her face-planting against walls intended for Carol to climb at least a few times each level.\nThe game's difficulty can also be frustrating; many, many parts of the game feel as though they're just right
column16: causing some of the boss fights to be impossibly hard by comparison. Lilac in particular will have a hard time finding ways to hit some of her bosses, as her normal attacks have too little reach to avoid damage, and her dash drains her entire special action meter when used. Most of the length of the bosses was spent waiting for the dragon dash to recharge. Carol faces similar problems on one boss in particular, where her wild kick needs to be managed carefully.\nThe last two paragraphs are definitely minor complaints surrounding what is possibly one of the most amazing games I've ever played. The entire experience gave my inner child an ear-to-ear smile. Pass this one up only if you absolutely don't like things that are fun.

reviewText:
In the interest of full disclosure, I've never really been a huge Sonic fan.  They're well put together, fun games, but I've always cottoned to Mega Man and Mario a bit more.  So I was intrigued by this game, but wasn't expecting it to get its hooks in.

Boy, was I wrong.

See, it's not really just Sonic, there's elements of all sorts of games in there, from Mega Man X to Gunstar Heroes to Rocket Knight.  And it's all fun stuff.  I love having a melee attack to use, as opposed to hopping and bopping.  I generally used Lilac, and it dawned on me that to some degree, there was some similarity between the feel of her attacks and Zero in Mega Man X4.  It's really good stuff.

Graphically, it's a really nice looking game.  Lots of creative little flourishes that probably wouldn't have made it on the Genesis, although stuff like Ristar came close.  It's more like a long-lost Saturn game, and this would have been exceptionally well received had it debuted on the Saturn.

Having multiple characters certainly improves the replay value, especially since each character has a couple of unique stages.  Not to mention they're different enough to change how things feel even in the overlapping stages.

The soundtrack is also very much praiseworthy.  Lots of upbeat, rockin' tunes.

The story has been much maligned, but I quite enjoyed it.  Is it rocket science?  Of course not.  It's going for a Saturday morning cartoon vibe, and outside of a few rather dark sequences, it nails it.  I found most of the voice acting well done as well.

If the game makes any missteps, it's that it gets pretty brutally hard towards the end.  The final boss, in particular, saw me drop around 30 lives before I finally sussed out the pattern.  I'm pretty sure I can repeat it at this point, but if you don't like tough, pattern-based bosses, you may find yourself frustrated.

Anyway, if you like Sonic, you might like this game.  If you positively ADORE Sonic, you might not like it, as it sprinkles in so many other elements that it becomes far more than a Sonic clone.  For me, that makes it fantastic, and well worth playing.  Two thumbs up, and definitely looking forward to a sequel!

reviewText: There is no shortage of retro styled indie platformers these days. Each one trying to be more hardcore and lo-fi than the last. We live in a golden age of games for people who love pixel perfect jumping and dying over and over again until they finally memorize the perfect path.\n\nFreedom Planet is not one of those games. It remembers that the reason we fell in love with platformers back in the day wasn't for the punishing challenge, but because it's just fun to blast through colorful levels filled with playful obstacles controlling cutesy characters with responsive controls and neat movesets. It's like discovering a long lost Genesis classic.

This gem is easily one of my favorite games ever. From the soundtrack to the gameplay to the art, this game is definitely worth your time.

The soundtrack is outstanding! It's got to be my favorite soundtrack of anything, ever. Seriously, go buy it.
The art style is gorgeous too. The characters' animations are all lifelike and colorful, and the bosses are awe-inspiring. Clearly a lot of work went into all the sprites. There's even a neat little easter egg in the third level where the characters dance!

reviewText: If you like classic Sonic games, or hell, any classic 2d platformer for that matter, chances are you'll adore Fredom Planet as well. reviewText:
Enormous levels, catchy music, cute character designs, gorgeous pixel art, perfectly matched level color palettes, forgiving difficulty curve, tons of rewards for exploring, the list of positives goes on.

The level of polish and detail in of each of the whopping [VERY MANY] levels and cutscenes speaks directly to the developer's love of 16/32-bit era platformers and of the Sonic franchise. It's not a Sonic clone but you can almost feel the sheer heart poured into this game to make it as faithful to this style of platformer as possible all while maintaining it's own identity and spirit.

This is Shovel Knight-levels of quality with nowhere near Shovel Knight-levels of attention. Let's change that!

reviewText:
Beat the main three characters playtroughs so doing a more overall review of the game.

I went into this game seeing JessieCox playing this and it seemed really cool so I decided play it myself. Several hours later I can without a doubt say this is one of the best games I've played in a very long time, if not one of the best I've played of all time.

As a person who grew up playing platformers like these, I already went in knowing I'd like it, but its not a cakewalk at all which some may take as a bad thing, but to have a game that actually is challenging is a nice thing compared to easy games that tend to be prevailant now. Many say its like a Sonic platformer, but I wouldn't really call it that alone. It's more of a combination of other platformers like Sparkster, Mega Man, Sonic, Rinstar, and others mixed into its own unique flavor. Game starts off decently easy letting you get to know how to use the characters, then it kicks it into overdrive and gets challenging (there are difficulty modes so those who don't want it to be as hard can have it this way). Level design is well done and interesting. Bosses get progressivly harder along with stages. There are three characters to play as who each play very differently than each other and each are sastifying to play as. Gameplay is pretty damn solid with nothing to say other than its really fun. You get to go fast and there aren't many momentum killing enemies. Nothing to gripe and its really damn fun to play. Story is actually pretty interesting too which I wasn't expecting since most of the time platformer games have minimal story that you tend to just put to the side if its even followable. Even playing classic mode (level to level with no story elements) its easy to catch on the story and follow along. I liked it a lot and wasn't too hard to follow in the midst of playing the game.

Visuals and the soundtrack are great as well. The graphics are a throwback to stuff back in the early/mid 90s which look really nice and run smoothly. The only thing one could gripe about visuals would be the slowdowns at a bosses defeat, but that is very minor and has no effect on actual gameplay.  The soundtrack is well beyond what I was expecting. From start the start I was instantly in love with it and it only got better the more I played. The boss music is easily in my top ever of just overall game music. The stage musics are also really great too. It was the one time I didn't even hesistate to buy the ost for it. I had to have it and support it. The only thing I could find some people could have a problem with in the audio department is the voice acting (cheesy), but then again, thats not a nack on the game at all. It didnt bother me (I actually liked some of them a lot)

Overall I'd have to say if you loved playing platformers back in the 90s or you just like good games, I highly recommend getting this. There are lots of things to strive for in the game from the achievements to unlocking stuff or just trying to beat your best time. The soundtrack is superb. The design is also superb. I haven't had this much fun playing a game in a while. If I had known of this when it was being kickstarted, I would have surely supported it as much as I could. I just love this so much. I can see myself still playing this a long time from now returning back to it many times.

reviewText: There is no shortage of retro styled indie platformers these days. Each one trying to be more hardcore and lo-fi than the last. We live in a golden age of games for people who love pixel perfect jumping and dying over and over again until they finally memorize the perfect path.\n\nFreedom Planet is not one of those games. It remembers that the reason we fell in love with platformers back in the day wasn't for the punishing challenge, but because it's just fun to blast through colorful levels filled with playful obstacles controlling cutesy characters with responsive controls and neat movesets. It's like discovering a long lost Genesis classic.

reviewText:
Freedom Planet began its development life as a Sonic the Hedgehog fangame, but the final product is so much more than that. At its heart, the game feels like an amalgamation of so many gaming memories from the nineties. Sonic is one, but there are also doses of Rocket Knight Adventures, Gunstar Heroes, Blaster Master... the whole thing is one big high-octane sixteen-bit thrillride which (apart from more modern touches like completely voiced dialogue and a rather lengthy story element in Adventure Mode) feels like it would have been considered a classic without question if it had come out back in the day.

That's not to say the game is perfect by any stretch. The story, while entertaining in terms of individual cutscenes, has a weird pace (occasionally taking ten minutes or so to get through a dialogue sequence), and shifts tone between dark and lighthearted a bit too jarringly, not to mention the plot itself is fairly simple (you can select Classic Mode to play the game through minus the story sequences, though). If I had to register a balance complaint, it would be that the game's bosses, while elaborate and certainly well-designed for what they are, feel like they belong in a much harder game--if you want anything resembling the sort of comfortable platformer difficulty that games like Sonic and Rocket Knight generally provide, you'll need to play on Easy difficulty--the bosses will kick your butt and grind it into a paste while you're working to get a handle on their patterns of attack, otherwise.

But the gameplay is solid and flowful, apart from some very rare collision-issue moments that I only suffered on replays; there are three characters, one unlockable, each offering a very unique gameplay style (the main character Lilac is my personal favorite and the one I recommend starting with). The level designs are all unique, if nothing wildly revolutionary for the genre, and the sense of pace, while somewhat slower than Sonic the Hedgehog (due in part to the greater emphasis on action elements) remains consistent throughout.

Put frankly, in spite of what flaws there are, I love this game and want nothing more than to get the word out there that it's a near-must-play for fans of the style of platformer that was popular back in the SNES and Genesis/Mega Drive era. It's only about five or so hours long at a stretch, but it provides more than enough fun factor and content for its $15 price point, as well. At the very least, do yourself a solid one and try out the demo. That in itself is fairly substantial, featuring a full stage and one act" of a second level.

As a side note
date: the music is also fantastic and el gasp
recommended: an indie game using pixel art that looks like it isn't just trying to look like pixel art because RETRO NOSTALGIA! I am almost in awe. Almost. Did I mention the game's very pretty-looking? Because it is."

reviewText:
This is not a Sonic clone, the physics are not the same and that is not a bad thing. The physics are more forgiving to the player and momentum can be built up easily. It works for this game as it is slightly more combat focused. You get to choose between three different characters.

Lilac: Is your speedy character that lets you boost around the level and enemies.

Carol: Is your melee focused character that can climb the level walls and scratch and kick enemies along the way.

Milla: Is your defence focused character which can block the attack from enemies to rebound back at them. Bosses/Enemies that may be difficult with Carol and Lilac can be very easy with Milla. Oh and she can Fly.

Playing with each character completely changes the way you navigate a level, it contains low paths, high paths and each route is faster and quicker depending on which character you end up using.
The game has 4 Difficulty options, Casual / Easy / Normal / Hard. So it has a great range of difficulties depending on how challenging you want the game.

I love the first Sonic games and I loved my Sega MegaDrive. This game feels like something from that era, and feels and plays amazingly. It's a lot of and fun and can get quite difficult at points. Especially the final boss fight, although the progression is very good so you should have a lot of fun along the way as you get better.

If you like fast/speedy platformers, then this is great. The developers have completely nailed this game. Music is also done to perfection, many tracks feel like something out of a Sonic game and it's fantastic.

If Shovel Knight was homage to old SNES games, then this is homage to SEGA classics. It's a shame it has not had the same amount of coverage in gaming media. Massively underrated.

*There is also a story mode with a lot of cheesy cutscenes. The voice acting is good and the characters are quite likable, but the story can drag on. You can play the game in 'Classic' mode which skips all the cutscenes automatically. Story mode is not the strong point of this game, though I still enjoyed it.

reviewText: I am truly Sonic the Hedgehog's biggest fan, and I love this game so much. But it's not because it's similar to Sonic, that's a VERY minor detail for me. It's a new game that I love with an incredible story and incredible characters that you just have to love, or in the case of the villains, hate for the right reasons. Any platformer fan should try this.\n\n+5 Review!

reviewText: This is an amazing game.\nFirst of all, Freedom Planet is a pleasure to the senses. The music and visual design marry to form an incredibly charming world. The foreground objects and background scenery are varied and feel alive with energy, from the natural out door areas through to the constructed, synthetic final areas. The character designs, even the tertiary and background characters, are appealing and feel like a good fit" to the world they inhabit. The voice acting isn't flawless
date: but even that works out in Freedom Planet's favor
recommended: adding a "Saturday Morning Cartoon" charm to the dialogue.\nI was personally very impressed with the way that the main characters are depicted; games featuring a strong female lead generally tend to over-emphiasize the hero's femininity or completely ignore it. There is also a tendency to make female heroes either too strong
hoursPlayed: or too weak
voteText: in comparison to their male counterparts. Freedom Planet pretty cleanly evades this entire hail of metaphorical bullets with Lilac and Carol. Though Carol is intended to be the more tomboy-ish of the pair
helpfulPercent: both manage to show us their strength and their weakness without ever needing to stop and remind the audience
votesHelpful: "Oh
votesTotal: by the way
votesFunny: I'm female
commentsCount: as though it's an excuse.\nWhile decidedly not a clone or a spin-off, Freedom Planet's roots as a Sonic the Hedgehog derived work show themselves in the level designs; expect to see ramps, looping circular paths, springs, switches, and other set peices normally unique to SEGA's 2D flagship series. As such, a number of them end up feeling out of place or clumsy (springs, in particular, cause Lilac to skid to an agonizing halt due to the momentum-handling). In general, the level layouts are probably the game's biggest shortcoming. Lilac and Carol (and later Mila) share stages, meaning that it needs to be possible for both characters (possessing radically different modes of movement) to complete said areas. Carol's motorcycle climbing ladders aside, Lilac's special action tends to send her face-planting against walls intended for Carol to climb at least a few times each level.\nThe game's difficulty can also be frustrating; many, many parts of the game feel as though they're just right
column16: causing some of the boss fights to be impossibly hard by comparison. Lilac in particular will have a hard time finding ways to hit some of her bosses, as her normal attacks have too little reach to avoid damage, and her dash drains her entire special action meter when used. Most of the length of the bosses was spent waiting for the dragon dash to recharge. Carol faces similar problems on one boss in particular, where her wild kick needs to be managed carefully.\nThe last two paragraphs are definitely minor complaints surrounding what is possibly one of the most amazing games I've ever played. The entire experience gave my inner child an ear-to-ear smile. Pass this one up only if you absolutely don't like things that are fun.

reviewText:
One giant love letter to character mascot platforming of ye olde 1990's. But be warned, this game cranks up the terrific controls, wonderful level design, and catchy music to 11/10. This is the best indie game I've ever played. If you want video game perfection, buy this game.

Oh, and the story reeks of stinky cheese. Thankfully, the developers had the idea to allow players to disable the story. Something I have to admit is quite revolutionary in video games today. I'm not joking.

In short, I love this game and I pray that you at least try the rather extensive demo.

reviewText:
In the interest of full disclosure, I've never really been a huge Sonic fan.  They're well put together, fun games, but I've always cottoned to Mega Man and Mario a bit more.  So I was intrigued by this game, but wasn't expecting it to get its hooks in.

Boy, was I wrong.

See, it's not really just Sonic, there's elements of all sorts of games in there, from Mega Man X to Gunstar Heroes to Rocket Knight.  And it's all fun stuff.  I love having a melee attack to use, as opposed to hopping and bopping.  I generally used Lilac, and it dawned on me that to some degree, there was some similarity between the feel of her attacks and Zero in Mega Man X4.  It's really good stuff.

Graphically, it's a really nice looking game.  Lots of creative little flourishes that probably wouldn't have made it on the Genesis, although stuff like Ristar came close.  It's more like a long-lost Saturn game, and this would have been exceptionally well received had it debuted on the Saturn.

Having multiple characters certainly improves the replay value, especially since each character has a couple of unique stages.  Not to mention they're different enough to change how things feel even in the overlapping stages.

The soundtrack is also very much praiseworthy.  Lots of upbeat, rockin' tunes.

The story has been much maligned, but I quite enjoyed it.  Is it rocket science?  Of course not.  It's going for a Saturday morning cartoon vibe, and outside of a few rather dark sequences, it nails it.  I found most of the voice acting well done as well.

If the game makes any missteps, it's that it gets pretty brutally hard towards the end.  The final boss, in particular, saw me drop around 30 lives before I finally sussed out the pattern.  I'm pretty sure I can repeat it at this point, but if you don't like tough, pattern-based bosses, you may find yourself frustrated.

Anyway, if you like Sonic, you might like this game.  If you positively ADORE Sonic, you might not like it, as it sprinkles in so many other elements that it becomes far more than a Sonic clone.  For me, that makes it fantastic, and well worth playing.  Two thumbs up, and definitely looking forward to a sequel!

reviewText:
It's a testament to how good the game actually is that it can remain super fun and enjoyable despite its problems, and the biggest problem in Freedom Planet is how deceptive the game is about it's difficulty.

Normal difficulty is well named up until the airship level. Past that, the game gets extremely difficult very quickly. Actually completing the game on normal difficulty requires a high level of skill.

If you're a strong platform gamer you'll probably still manage to complete it, but it will absolutely test your skills. Even if you do complete the game, you will likely feel frustrated, as the difficulty comes unexpectedly.

There are segments you will not complete on your first try, simply because you can't anticipate the danger. Gotcha!" moments are way too common in the late game.

This can be very discouraging at times!

If Freedom Planet called normal mode "hard mode
date: and hard mode very hard mode
recommended:
that be an improvement. It'd at least give the player an honest idea of what to expect.

I really, really enjoyed Freedom Planet, but it is absolutely not a game I can recommend to everyone.

At the very least, I'd advice anyone who isn't confident in their platformer skills to play on Easy difficulty first.

reviewText:
Freedom Planet is my favorite game that I've played this year. I bought it during the 2015 summer sale last week for about $4, but if I knew how good it was I probably would've been willing to spend ten times that much on it.

I was always more of a Nintendo kid than a Sega kid growing up, so I don't have too much nostalgia for the Genesis games that Freedom Planet tries to emulate. However, I did enjoy Sonic 2 and Sonic 3 & Knuckles, and I feel like I enjoyed this game just as much as those. Sonic is definitely the most obvious design inspiration (most obviously in the level structure), but Freedom Planet also takes a lot of ideas from other 16-bit games like Rocket Knight Adventures, Ristar, and Mega Man X. The bosses in particular are some of the best I've ever seen, and are just as good as anything in Gunstar Heroes.

It's clear that a lot of work went into making the 3 playable characters feel very dynamic and fun to play. They are all VERY different, and none of them truly play like Sonic as you might expect. The game is balanced around Lilac, who is sort of a hybrid of Sonic, Ristar, and Sparkster with some fighting game moves like an uppercut and a dive kick. However, I initially played through the entire game as Carol, who is much closer to Zero from Mega Man X4, with a fast combo-oriented claw attack and a wall jump. She also has a bizarrely awesome motorcycle that can double jump and drive straight up vertical walls. I'm impressed that the game still felt well designed and balanced despite playing with a character who works completely differently from Lilac.

After around level 3, the bosses become extremely difficult, absurdly so relative to the stages themselves. And there are a lot of them, generally 2-3 per level. However, they are not truly unfair. Even with the notoriously difficult final boss, I was able to figure out his pattern enough to know how to beat him without taking a single hit... though I'm unable to play with enough skill to actually manage that. Fortunately, the game is generous with lives and checkpoints; I died 70 times throughout the entire game with Carol on Normal (20 of those deaths were on the final boss), but I never saw a game over. So the game is definitely hard, but it does encourage and reward skillful play.

A lot of people don't like the story, but I found it somewhat charming, reminiscent of all those early 90s Saturday morning cartoons starring anthropomorphic animals that took themselves slightly too seriously. It is admittedly darker and more violent than those ever got, as you'll see during the introduction. However, the characters themselves keep things lighthearted 99% of the time. The voice acting is excellent (apart from the overly hammy king in the introduction, who gives a lousy first impression), and it's clear the actors had tons of fun during recording. Some of the cutscenes do go on far longer than they should; the worst offender is between levels 2 and 3. Fortunately, if you don't want to deal with cutscenes there is a specific option to play story mode without any of them.

My only other complaint is that the levels, while well designed, are probably longer than they should be. Not so much because they get boring, as the game introduces new mechanics and environments at a good pace, but because they can be exhausting. The game is generous with checkpoints, but saves only happen between levels, so you'll have to complete each of the 15-40 minute levels all in one session. I would have preferred that each level be cut in half, much like how Sonic's Zones have two Acts; the levels are clearly designed in halves, even with different music for each part, so I don't know why this wasn't done.

In summary, Freedom Planet is an excellent game, and I give it my highest recommendation. This and Shovel Knight should serve as examples of how to do retro gaming well, reaching a level of quality that stands shoulder to shoulder with the greatest games of the eras they seek to emulate.

reviewText:
This game is amazing. It has interesting characters, levels, and a good story, and amazing voice actors. That's right this game is fully voice acted, and all of them are great. Every level has new enemy types so you'll rarely see them reused, the maps are just as diverse. There are three playable characters Lilac the Dragon, Carol the Wildcat, and Milla the Basset Hound. All of them play wildly different and have different levels specific to their particular character meaning that even on your third play through you'll still be seeing new content. That's not even counting the time trials or collectables.

The game loses point for being quite hard to play without a controler, not impossible, just hard. On the topic of hard the game is difficult but you always feel like it's your fault you died. The bosses are difficult and require you to learn their patterns to beat with any level of ease. You'll quickly find which character is your favourite and start ripping through the opposition... mostly.

You'll see a lot of people comparing this to Sonic games, as someone who has never played a Sonic game (aside from Sonic 06) this is exactly what I imagined Sonic games to be like. It's fun, it's fast, it's interesting, and it's full of content. I've played for 8 hours and I've only beat the game with one character, have next to none of the time trials done, and about 10% of the collectables.

Do yourself a favour and buy this game. My friend introduced me to it, so play it, love it, and tell all your friends. If this game can become a series I'm certain it will eclipse Sonic games very soon. While Sonic is surely a great series I don't have to play it to know there hasn't been a good one in ages.

If I had to rate this game I'd give it a 9/10. Full of interesting content, hours worth of fun. but there are some glitches and I'd highly reccomend playing with a controler if you have one.

reviewText:
If you like platformers, get  Freedom Planet . It's  one of the best indie platformers I've ever played .

First of all, by just looking at the trailer or a screenshot, you can tell  this game looks gorgeous : it has one of the most detailed pixel art graphics I've ever seen and the music is amazing. I found the story interesting for a 2D game and playing as the different characters you get to see the story in their perspective ( slightly ). And the voice acting is pretty neat, again, for a 2D game.

Everybody compares this to sonic but when you play it; you realize how different and unique this game is. There’s a variety of stages with creative gimmicks and  the characters have really original abilities  but you can try this by yourself by  playing the demo .
Unlike sonic, the game tells you about the danger ahead,  enemies don’t damage you by touching them  only their attacks,  only 2 stages have bottomless pits , you can’t really get crushed so  there’s no cheap deaths here . The stages are long but they never feel boring and they contain a lot of secrets with their respective bosses and mid-bosses. It’s more combat-focused since every character has a big range of attacks; that’s why  the bosses and the action sequences are the best part of the game .

I really don’t see any bad thing in this game , pointing out minor details would sound very forced. Maybe there’s a lack of information on the characters moves since it looks like the characters have an specific list of moves and attacks but they have much more than what you would think ( I guess it’s fun to find out by yourself ).
Anyways, I would say this game is  epic  and that’s a word I rarely use.
