reviewText:
Freedom Planet caught my eye on the front page of Steam during the summer sale with its cute and colorful art style, and once I watched the trailer and read a couple reviews I decided to impulse buy it. And wow am I glad that I did.

This game is an action platformer that is similar to the original Sonic the Hedgehog games. Now I've never been a huge Sonic fan, only playing a few of the games casually, but I was instantly hooked to Freedom Planet the minute I started playing. It's fast paced (without the same momentum that Sonic games have that kind of force you to keep moving), has a colorful pixel art style, a great soundtrack, and the story is exciting and packed with creative characters and a cute sense of humor. Plus, if you're not a fan of stories and just want the gameplay, you can play on classic mode. The gameplay is fun and challenging, with unique levels and boss fights, and there's a time attack mode if you are looking for an extra challenge. And each level has a lot of room for exploration, plus there are collectible cards in each level that will keep you playing over and over again.

Seriously, Freedom Planet is an amazingly fun game with lots of replay value that I wish more people knew about. It is well worth the price, whether you get it on sale or decide to purchase it for the full price.

How to put a description of Freedom Planet into words...

reviewText:
Now...What I was expecting when I saw this and downloaded it was a fun little romp of sonic styled gaming with voice acting with some unique looking twists...What I got...Well ya, was that but ooooh so much more.

The Good!: This game brings everything about 90's gaming together, Elements, of Sonic, Rocket Knight, Megaman X, Mario, Gunstar heros and castlevania and goes even further beyond that to not only blend these elements beautifully, but do it while maintaining it's own identity. The level design is brilliant for the different styles of gameplay with the various characters you can play, having each character able to tackle the level in different ways. It's a fresh feeling being able to blaze a level as Lilac and then play it again as Carol to take a slower but more action and explorative approach...Till you get the motorcycle and just rocket off having a blast. The Music is catchy and beautiful and I don't thing there was a single track I wouldn't just sit down and listen too. When I get a 1up and it plays a jingle, I'm ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at the jingle for cutting off the music cause it's so good...The same doesn't apply for the invinciblity tune, I wish that one would play forever...The last gem to me is the story, something I wasn't expecting to be as good as it was. I enjoyed the character immensely as each felt unique with well fleshed out and likeable personalities...IN A PLATFORMER...Seriously back in the genesis and SNES days, what was Mario's character or personallity? Sonic had more personality, but what was his motivation. The old games were just BAM Here's the level off you go. As this game goes their motivations are done up very well as to why the villan needs to be stopped and the impact it has on the characters and the voice acting, though not the best, is rather engaging and gives it a great charm that further helps establish it's own identity.

The Bad...: The biggest draw back for most and most glaring is gonna be the lenghty cutscenes. If your not expecting it and aren't into long cutscenes it's gonna be a downer for you. They're skippable and if you want to avoid them completely you can play a classic mode to play the game just like the old Sonic and Mario games of yesteryear. Another problem is there's a bit of a difficulty curve when it comes to the later bosses. I breezed throught the first 3 levels or so without a single death but from then on bosses started unleashing heavy damaging attacks and not seeing them for the first time resulted in me unable to react fast enough and taking a ton of damage. It gets pretty bad at the end where the final boss killed me about 30 times before I finally figured out a strategy, but for oldschool gaming, higher difficulty could be a welcom challenge. Lives don't seem to be a big issue as even if you game over, you can continue pretty much where you left off...See dying to final boss 30 times. I continued 3 times and picked up right where I left off, didn't even need to fight the previous forms...So what was the point of lives? The most shocking aspect of the game was how DARK the story got at times, I mean the villan is cold blooded to the point I wonder how the hell this game is rated E...

Over all I adored this game, I expected a quick little game to past by weekend off on and got a Gem I hadn't expected. I highly recommend it for any classic 90's gaming fans, sonic fans, or even just platformer fans.

reviewText: Freedom Planet is a great game that combines classic Sonic The Hedgehog game play with modern voice acting and story line, while also allowing the option for classic game play without any of the story or voicing. The diverse abilities of Lilac, Carol and Milla are as different from each other as night and day..... and evening.... cuz, three characters.... three times of day..... Yeah.... The admittedly simple controls, and quick-play action with the low quality almost classic Genesis type graphics allows for nice easy play style with little to no lag on any computer. The levels are each designed to bring about some type of challenge, whether it be the stage length and just sticking until the end, a small puzzle to move on, an immense amount of enemies swarming your hide with every step, or a boss who's weakspot is so tough to find that it has you pulling your hair out to find it. In the end, this is a must play game if you like classic Sonic The Hedgehog type games, sidescrollers, epic boss battles, or just want something to play on your free time.

reviewText:
First off, let me say that I've always considered the classic 2D Sonic games as okay and meh. I liked the concept of a platformer focussed around active movement and light combat, but the little things like the annoying life/ring system just killed it for me. Thankfully, Freedom Planet takes the concept of Sonic the Hedgehog and greatly improves upon it with slight adjustments and new ideas that make it a true spiritual succesor worth experiencing.

Gameplay: Basically what you would expect the gameplay is mostly composed of free-running, jumping and getting your hands dirty in a scrappy fight now and then. It's all easy to learn but somewhat difficult to master what with the different factors to keep in mind like the character's magic/stamina bar, the weaknesses of the enemies as well of the current surroundings. The main character: Lilac's style is best described as graceful and practical with attacks and moves that can compliment each other once you've practiced on the first level or two, and Carol is much more adept at fighting than she is running, making her motorcycle power-up all the more entertaining and special once you get one. With their own slight strengths and weaknesses, Freedom Planet is one of the few platformer games with multiple characters in which the characters are noticeably different without one being easier to use. The only complaint I have with the overall gameplay is that you don't really get informed of the character's lesser known abilities. It was longer than I'm proud to admit before I found out that Carol can wall-jump or that Lilac can do her cyclone" while running on the ground. But even this set-back is nothing considering that learning by doing and experimenting is always greatly preferred to the alternative of annoying tutorials and the like.

Story: Without wanting to spoil too much
date: the story starts out small with a hectic "political conundrum" and later builds up to a world-threatening catastrophe. Each character has their own personality with fair imperfections that become more noticeable as time goes on. I was surprised at how much subtle emotion was depicted from even the secondary characters who hardly had any screen time. It makes for an interesting set-up and gives just enough context to motivate you to keep moving forward in case the option to just skip the story isn't preferred. The worst things to say about the story is that if you decide to skip even one cutscene then you'll probably feel a bit lost when you get to the next one since a lot tends to happen in such little time
recommended: and also that the main characters in the story are so friendly and innocent that it's more than understandable why an older player might get turned away.\n\nAnything else: All in all
hoursPlayed: this is an amazing platformer and an incredible game. It's overflowing with pure entertainment
voteText: and I find myself coming back to it more than I ever would've ever guessed when I first made my purchase. I think if anything
helpfulPercent: my favorite thing about this game is that it has more replay value than 90% of other newly released games. There isn't any doubt in my mind that I'll still be revisiting these wonderful levels five years from now."

reviewText:
It's not possible to review this game without drawing comparisons to Sonic the Hedgehog. It's not. But if I had to choose between Sonic the Hedgehog 3 and going another round with this game, I'd have to say Freedom Planet would own my afternoon.

At first, I was leary of this game. The graphics didn't look all too impressive from a glance at the screenshots, and $15 seemed a little steep for me to take a risk. But for whatever reason, I did. And after playing through the first few levels, I deeply regret ever doubting the quality of this game. The levels, characters, and just EVERYTHING were all lovingly crafted by the developers, and it shows. And while the game hosts a number of obvious similarities to the blue hedgehog's glory days games, I daresay that Freedom Planet does it all far better, right down to the core mechanics of the game. Even if you didn't really enjoy any Sonic games, I'd still recommend this game, because it is something else altogether.

Admittedly, I don't care terribly for the difficulty curve. Because while the difficulty raises over time throughout the course of the game, it fluxuates wildly within the level, ranging from a gentle summer breeze to DEAR CHRIST IN HEAVEN SPARE ME THIS TRIBULATION. You also accumulate lives way too easily. If it were my decision, I would abolish lives altogether, and rather start the player off at the beginning of the current board whenever you die. But I suppose it's a little late to be going back and making such colossal redesigns as that. Also, the game has VOICE ACTING! And it's not atrocious! It's nothing amazing, but it's still good. And that's pretty damn impressive.

Difficulty aside, it's a great game that I would easily recommend for any fan of the action-platformer genre.

reviewText:
I will be honest and say that as much as I love Sonic the Hedgehog, I am not really a big fan of his classic games. I have played all of them (Sonic 1-3), but find them too frustrating, especially when losing all those rings I painstakingly gathered for those special stages from one hit. I know it all comes down to skill in the end, but still...

So I was surprised when I bought Freedom Planet and have found myself coming back to play it over and over again.

Freedom Planet is unquestionably inspired by Sonic the Hedgehog. It even started out as a fan game but evolved into its own unique experience. I saw this game through a review on YouTube and was really curious from the start, downloading the demo and later buying the full thing. I spoiled nothing save for looking at one stage not included in the demo, but that was it. Everything was a complete blank until I began playing.

So with that said, is this game worth the price tag it comes along with? Absolutely!! If you are a fan of Sonic the Hedgehog, then you will most likely enjoy this game. Don't mistake it for a clone, because it is not. Freedom Planet is it's own unique game, adopting sonic mechanics such as high-speed platforming while adding combat, intense boss fights that will have your reflexes tested throughout, and unique play styles that, while subtlety different, don't change your overall experience of the game. The story is fun in my personal opinion, but plays a lot with its tone and pacing, so keep that in mind when you choose story mode. The graphics are really pretty to look at, and the music beautifully captures the atmosphere of the stage you are in.

Freedom Planet is definitely a game worth picking up if you are into the 2D platformers, especially if you are a Sonic fan.

Also, motorbikes that defy physics altogether. Have fun!!

reviewText:
A remake of the GOOD Sonic games.
The combat is way better, the running is... eh. not as good. It's good, but not as good as the classic Sonics. The story and plot are ok; not great, but WAY better than what passes for Sonic now-a-days (and you can turn off the story if you want).

Some of the levels are very clear homages to Sonic levels, with matching music. The music is so-so, not as good as Sonic 2 or 3. Turn off music in the settings and play an OC Remix Sonic album and you'll have a really good time.

The characters are all rendered and written 2D (see what I did there?) but their move-sets are all very unique and even their play-styles are a bit different, especially with the third character.

5/5 Would beat another 3 times.

reviewText:
I don't often write reviews, but I also don't often get sucked into a game as hard as I did with this one. I've always been a huge fan of the Sonic games, and while it would be accurate to say that this is inspired in some ways by classic Sonic (Sonic CD, to be more specific), it is SO much more than that, and it is a disservice to this game to say that it is a Sonic clone or knock-off.

First and foremost, this is an amazing platformer with an enormous, beautifully realized world. The sprite work is the best and most detailed of any game I've seen, and there is a ridiculous amount of enemy variety. The physics of the game are pretty good, though I'm not a fan of the super-generous wall walking. You don't really need any speed at all to climb any slope, including going upside down.

The game is also hard as nails in spots, and while it doesn't always feel fair, you will never have to redo a full stage because a boss used up all your lives. Hell, even the final boss fight is generous enough that if you get a game over during the fight you start over at the beginning of the phase you were just on.

The voice acting is a bit spotty, which should come as no surprise, since this is the first role of most of the cast. The writing can be a bit campy, but it's never so bad that it becomes unbearable.

Also, there's a ton of replay value. Time Trial mode, classic mode (no cutscenes, just action), hundreds of collectible pieces of art and music, and three playable characters all with drastically different play styles.

If you're only interested in the classic mode, or plan to skip through the cutscenes, it can be a little short... might want to wait for a sale. If you're looking for a fun game with a cute story that isn't afraid of getting dark, then you can't go wrong with Freedom Planet.

reviewText:
Akin to Shovel Knight, which pays homage to the glory of NES games, Freedom Planet is considered one of the finest tributes to Genesis titles. It is said to be a combination of Sonic, Rocket Knight, Ristar and Gunstar Heroes (none of which I've actually played, to be honest).

Being a Sonic fangame in the very beginning, Freedom Planet obviously resembles it the most, but mind you, this is not some kind of knock off. Its mechanics mix the elements of speed, combat and exploration in such a way, that you are free to be a runner, fighter or explorer and change your style at your heart's desire.

In the core mechanics we have a traditional health system, an actual combat system with a variety of moves and some very forgiving physics that does not aim to hinder your progress, so that you are able to climb any wall as long as your speed is not below walking. Sometimes physics behave really weird to the point that you might think that it is glitching (I'm looking at you, girder see-saw!), but such occurences are very rare and do not lead to anything harmful.

The level design offers wide stages, often with multiple paths, and without areas that force you to halt your movement for long. Almost every stage introduces some new element that adds enough diversity to make it feel fresh but not totally different. Graphics is colorful and very well made.
It is very worth noting, that the game has no such pleasant" things as random bottomoless pits and wide rows of instakill spikes. Seeing an instakill contraption occurs as often as holidays
date: and the rare presence of pits is absolutely justified
recommended: plus the latter can be easily avoided if you apply just a little common sense and careness. So death here never feels cheap.\n\nAnother thing deserving mentioning is the lack of yet another traditional staple of running and platforming games - the contact damage. Enemies need to actively attack you to harm you (unless they are covered with spikes or fire). The resulting effect greatly helps the flow
hoursPlayed: no need to fear that you'll stop dead after colliding with some baddie - they won't stop your running.\n\nMovement and combat feel very fluid and responsive
voteText: platforming does not induces frustration

reviewText:
This game has been an amazing experience for me. I never grew up with a genesis, a SNES, or anything like that. My first system was a gamecube.
Yet despite this, I can feel nostalgia being drawn from the few genesis-style platfromers I've played, such as Sonic Advance.
It's not just about nostalgia, though. This is a very well crafted game that almost perfectly captures what makes high speed platformers so special while also adding new mechanics to liven things up.
It's like a heartfelt love letter to the Glory days of Sega and Treasure.
Everything from the animation to the soundtrack melds together to form a virtually perfect experience.
Just buy it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The first thing people are going to do when they see this game is compare it to Sonic.  Is this a fair justification?  Yes, and only if you're willing to admit that there are people who make better Sonic games than Sega.  There are two ways to play Freedom Planet.  Story mode, complete with cutscenes, fantastic voice acting, and of course the gameplay, and arcade mode which plays like any 2D Adventure game from the Sega Genesis days.  So just what makes this game so damn fun?

First of all, it controls well.  If you're going to have characters platform and do it quickly, they need to be able to control well.  The only thing to say about this is.....NAILED IT.  Yup, the multiple(did I mention that yet?) characters each control very well and navigate through the levels very well.  Taking a nod back to the classic sonic games, each character has their own quirk if you will that will allow them to traverse the level differently, which can lead to different encounters, and more importantly different gameplay mechanics leading to a ridiculously high replay value. Furthermore, the game switches nicely between speed segments, platforming, lite puzzle solving, and combat to keep you interested the whole time.  On top of all this cake, we have the icing, which is very well done boss battles.

I am giving this game a lot of praise because I haven't had this much fun with a 2D platformer like this since Sonic 3 & Knuckles.  So, it's been a while.  I love this game and want nothing more than to share with you one of the finest creations this decade.  Freedom Planet gets nothng less than a perfect score.

10+/10                 Replay Value: Obnoxiously High

reviewText:
Although some parts were frustrating for me at the end, since I'm not spectacular at action platformers, I think this is quite possibly the most fun action platformer game that I've ever played, including classics like Sonic and the Mario games. At least for me, this games art style, story, enjoyable characters all with good voice acting, combat done well, enemy variety, story, music, atmosphere, setting, humor, and overall emotional investment the adventure mode allows the player to have with the characters all come together to make a very fun and enjoyable experience.

There is some cheesiness in some of the dialogue and story, but in a funny, well placed way. Beyond that, I feel like some of the different moves that can be pulled off can be a little awkward, but it depends on the control setup I suppose. All controls are easily rebindable, as is joystick sensitivity, so I might need to tweak that more, as some of the mild floatiness and jumping precision were probbly on my end, as everything else felt very tight.

One of the most fun aspects of the game for me was how much the overall style of presentation encourages a very go get 'em" attitude. The characters can take quite a number of hits before dying

reviewText:
This game is pretty much a fan made spiritual sequel to 16-bit Sonic games. If you enjoyed them, then I highly recommend this game! While it is obviously inspired by Sonic, it still plays differently enough to have its own identity. There are three different characters that all play differently. All females, and the main character Lilac really looks like a character that could be from Sonic series. She totally looks like a hedgehog (well, as much as Sonic does), apparently it says she's a dragon.

There is a story mode with full voice acting, something I did not expect from a game that uses 16-bit art style, so that's pretty nice. I have to give my respect for the developers and voice actors, for actually making a quite lenghty cutscenes for a retro platformer. For those who don't care about the story there is Classic Mode, which removes all story and cutscenes.

But the main thing is that the gameplay is good and fun. Pixel graphics are well done and the music is nice too. Stages are mostly good, but it kinda makes me wish there would be even more possibilites for going fast. Boss fights are mostly good too.

One thing that I this game shouldn't have is lives. Shovel Knight was another retro style platformer, and it understood that lives are an outdated system.

The worst part? The lives are totally meaningless! You still start from the checkpoint when you get a game over. During the stages you collect a huge amount of little blue crystals and I think every time you get 200, you get a life. You think that collecting them is rewarding now?

Collect enough of these little items and you get an extra life" is a classic system that almost every mascot platformer had back in the days
date: but it's one thing that never was rewarding for me in the first place.\n\nOkay
recommended: I'm getting a little off track here. The bottom line is that it's a well made retro platformer
hoursPlayed: and all platformer fans should try it."

reviewText:
So after picking this up on the cheap, I have a few things to say.

Firstly, yes, it looks tile a Sonic clone, and it kinda is. But that isnt a bad thuing. The Early sonic games were brilliant, and im my oppinion should have stayed 2D, but thats a whole different discusion. This Game however brings back that enjoyment i used to get, and more so. The game play is slower than a sonic game, but thankfully doesnt do any cheap tricks like sticking spikes at the end of holding right for 5 minutes. This game is also has a lot more platforming, so you arent alwasy running one direction.

2. The music and visuals are lovely. You can see where the inspiration for the characters comes from, but thats okay, beacasue they are there own charcters, not straight up genderbent clones. As you prgress through the game you find cards that unlock the stages music, so you can enjoy that sweet Relic Runes 2 music to your hearts content, Or you can even get the soundtrqack, surely that shows its a commendable factor. The voice acting is suprisingly good too, a pleasent suprise as i wasnt expecting any.

C. The game play is solid, with minimal controls. This doesnt stop each character feling different however. I would recommend a controller if possible, but really isnt necessary, As previsouly mentioned it is slower then sonic games, which i think is a good thing. The only downside to this is that you can basically stick to walls, walking verticle at a casual stroll pace. This seems jenky at first, but if you can accept it, then its all good in da hood.

I would reccomend this game. At full price. But as steam sales are a thing apprently, not sure if you guys know about them, When this goes on sale i would say its a definate purchase. I would be very very suprised if you didnt get your moneys worth and more in enjoyment from this brilliant title. I look forward to possibly more in the series.

reviewText: Really impressive effort for what is essentially a Sonic fangame.  It's a little rough around a few edges (mostly from a production standpoint; for example, the VOs aren't well mastered or mixed consistently), but the game is legitimately better than anything developed by Team Sonic since Sega stopped making their own hardware. reviewText:
This game is absolutely fantastic: the sprites are beautiful, the gameplay is excellent, and the music is porn for the ears.
However, this game is not for everyone. The plot, while having some lighthearted moments, is EXTREMELY dark, featuring decapitation and torture (multiple times, may I add!). The difficulty is also extraordinarily high, with the later levels being insanely harsh.

Also, a warning: This game's final boss will beat you to the ground. It will make you cry. It will kill you after you are already dead... seriously.
Overall, the game is an easy 9/10, albiet if you're easily enraged it's an 8/10.

reviewText:
THE BEST SONIC GAME NEVER MADE - 8/10

I've put a lot of thought into this review to keep it unbiased and critical, so please enjoy.
Now i'm gonna just throw this out there; I'm a huge retro 'Sonic the Hedgehog' fan. At two years old it was the first game i remember playing, and it's always firmly been my favourite series of games. I will forever praise it as being a technological marvel  with top notch gameplay that holds up to this very day. Nothing will ever replace that 70% of my heart that is owned by Sonic 3 & Knuckles. Nothing. But even after all this -

Freedom Planet is better. And it sure as hell ain't a Sonic clone.

It's an absolute gem of a game that needs far more recognition than it currently has. The story, characters, visuals and music are all very reminiscent of a saturday morning cartoon. It's the first thing that sprang to mind with it's cheesy dialogue, narrator and it's typical bad guy trying to take over the universe storyline. You just need to watch the trailer to understand what i'm taking about, it's dripping with the stuff you most likely loved as a kid. I've heard people complain that the dialogue is awful but i don't think they quite understand the design choice here. The story plays a far larger part of the game here than in most 2D platformers. There are cutscenes and even dialogue during some levels, and it's all really fantastic to watch IMO, but if that's not your thing and you want to get straight into the action you can play on Classic mode, which removes all cutscenes and leaves you with a typical 2D platformer level after level progression.

The soundtrack is the best i've heard since Shovel Knight, it fits perectly with the world and the games pace. I would recommend searching 'Fortune Night Act 2' on Youtube (my personal favourite, because guitars). It doesn't loop for some reason in the game though, which is kinda weird.
www.youtube.com/watch?v=LkggMLlR2RU

The visuals in the game are fanastic, incredibly detailed pixel art. The world is beautifully designed and every area feels very different from the last. It keeps you interested throughout and doesn't feel stale. You won't always be playing the same levels though. There are three different story routes you can take, one for each character, and some of the levels are unique to certain characters, which brings me on to the most important part; THE GAMEPLAY.

As i mentioned there are multiple characters you can play as, and they all play rather differently. You've got the love child of Sonic and Rocketknight, 'Lilac the Dragon', who will probably be most peoples favourite. Her gameplay is more focused on speed, using a Rocketknight style boost mechanic to allow nice fluid action. You've got 'Carol the Wildcat' who can climb on walls and ride a motorbike. The motor bike allows her to rival Lilacs speed but is only available as a pickup. And finally there's 'Milla the...ummm, psychic dog?'. Not quite sure,of that one. She has the slowest gameplay and her levels are more about puzzle solving. I've not played much of her story yet so i can't fully comment. All characters have fast and intense gameplay, just some more than others. Combat is incredibly fun as well, you dont' jump on enemies heads, you have a number of attacks unique to each character. Lilac can boost into enemies, spin around in a flurry or perform punch and kick combos. Carol is more focus on her punch and kick combos being a martial artist, and can also use her motorbike to flatten enemies. Milla can shoot blasts of psychic energy at her foes making her gameplay more Megaman-esque. There is a lot of replayability here when it comes to trying different characters. The bosses are also incredibly tough to beat, even once you've figured out their patterns. They are very well designed, fast paced and so challenging that beating them feels like such an achievement. They will kill you a lot but it never feels cheap, there is always a pattern to learn.

So i've praised this game to the high heavens, but it of course has its flaws, which mainly come in the category of level design and physics. You see, these levels are huge. So incredibly big that you can imagine a lot of the art assets are reused over and over, so a lot of the time it's very difficult to know exactly where you are in a level, even after playing it numerous times. Now this wouldn't be a problem at all, it's great that every time you play it you could find a different route that you don't recognise, but they've done something that just doesn't work harmoniously with this mish-mashy level design, and that's collectible hunting. Now this in no way ruins the game itself, it's completely optional and mainly for the achievement i reckon, but that's another thing that makes it a bit flimsy, it's mainly for an achievement". The player has to find 10 hidden cards throughout each level and as you can imagine when there are huge levels with kinda similar looking areas this is going to be no easy feat. It's a minor gripe though since it's completely optional. As for the physics
recommended: but not in any way that will ruin your game experience. Example being if you jump upwards towards a sloped ceiling you'll automatically start running on it
hoursPlayed: which is kinda weird. Also in a similar fashion to Sonic 4 you can just walk up vertical walls and don't have to be going at full speed. I also find it far too easy to lose momentum. It doesn't take long running up a vertical slope before you start lightly jogging

reviewText:
Ill get it out of the way, this game is very “Sonic” In character design and level design. That’s where the similarities end though, Freedom Planet is a very different beast and really deserves to be judged on its own merits. Freedom Planet is more a action game then a speedy platformer. Sure there are parts where you will be booking it through loop-de-loops but it blends combat in with it seamlessly and the levels lend themselves well to it. See most enemies don’t hurt you on contact, so you have two options. Blaze through the level and hit the occasional enemy on the way or stick around and fight it out. Both options are fine and both have there rewards and the game gives you everything you need to do it.

From the offset the game has three characters to play and all of them play drastically different. There’s Lilac who is more well rounded and great for first time players, Carol who can really kick ♥♥♥ with skillful play and Milla who is meant to be played slowly and more carefully and is really built for exploring the levels and finding shiny things. All of these characters are viable in all the different levels and they even each have there own levels unique to them. Each character is like playing a different game and most of the levels are balanced so every character has there own way of getting around them. There are even areas that only certain characters can access. It can be very difficult to build levels with multiple characters in mind and they have done a great job of it.

I will say some of the bosses can take a while to really get a bead on however the game pretty much lets you try again as much as you want until you finally get it right and that moment when you do can really be satisfying. The game does use a lives system but with how the continues work its really just kind of window dressing which is a bit of a oversight but it didn’t bother me too much. Though that makes going for the games main collectible Crystals kind of moot since all it really does is give you lives unless you care about high scores or bragging rights. I do really wish they could have reworked it cause the idea of doing away with lives period wouldn’t hurt me in the slightest. The reason I stuck with it til the end was because I DIDN’T have to start a level over, I actually had a chance to learn instead of drop the game out of frustration. Lives are a product of the times, when the games were all about eating quarters. I feel like lives are a outdated relic of the past and its just not good game design anymore, hardcore gamers be damned, but really its just a small nitpick on a otherwise great game.

I do want to end on a positive note though. I’m proud this game opted to have not one, not two but THREE female protagonists who are fun and interesting. I will say that while the story itself is pretty good its not super spectacular, But I do like how you get different pieces of the story depending on who you play and it does add good replay value. The characters are what really saved it for me. The writing is fun and the voice acting is also well done for having a lot of unknown actors. Having three female protagonists is really a breath of fresh air in a game industry ruled by scruffy white guys.

I highly recommend Freedom Planet especially if you’ve been craving a Sonic styled platformer like the good old days that feels like a long lost Saturn game. They plan on adding more content for free later including 2 new characters with there own parts of the story to play which frankly im very excited for. Give this game a look.

reviewText:
If you like 90's platformers and your eyeing this game carefully, dont bother waiting anymore, you will be glad you bought it. One of those games that are better on the second run lel. So this is a 2d platformer heavily inspired by alot of classic 90's games. If youre good, the game play will be fast and fun. It borrows alot of level design that make the old sonic games great and improve some that dont, but they built the game so it doesnt play just like a sonic game. If you are at all interested in this game, i recommend playing carol first. However, the story is outright worthless due to a meh plot and meh voice acting. But thats okay, just choose classic mode, dont feel bad about missing out on the story theres not much to grieve about. The art style has well done pixel art with incredible detail all while the amazing level design makes the game a joy to play.

If i had to complain about the gameplay, there are some moments where you are just waiting for your special bar to fill and it breaks the flow (especially with lilac, play carol first. Lilac is fun, but only once you get used to things because its not a sonic game). I also think levels were too long for my tastes, levels go on for about 10 minutes on your first time through but not once you get good. I think theres an unbalance in difficulty: levels are easy and straight forward, but the bosses are tough. once you figure out the attack patterns theyre not impossible but you will lose plenty of lives just trying to figure them out (but theres no punishment for death at all so atleast they dont make you rage quit).

Its a fun game that kinda grew on me because its better the second time you play it IMO. Solid game play 7/10

reviewText:
Remember the good old days when Sonic games didn't suck? Freedom Planet gives you exactly that - speed, loops, attitude - in a package that feels like it could've been on an actual 16-bit cartridge, with worlds that are fun to explore and loot of hidden items, lots of charm in every character, and some of the best cutscenes I've ever seen in an indie game. A must-buy if you're old enough to have fond Sonic memories.

The three playable characters also play radically differently - Lilac has a Sparkster-style charge attack that lets her cover big distances of open space quickly and a double jump that doubles as a slow descent AND an attack, her cat sidekick can climb walls indefinitely and has a strong attack that's easy to aim, making her the most conventional character and the easiest to get into altough she can't enter all alternate routes. Finally, Milla the rabbit can conjure blocks, reflect enemy attacks and fly, but has half the health of the other two girls, making her an advanced character that is really tricky to master but potentially the best to speedrun with.

I'm just at the 3rd stage so far, but I can recommend this game considerably - it might just be as good as Shovel Knight if it keeps this up!

reviewText:
A friend of mine recommended me this game and I shrugged it off for a while. 2 Months later I looked into it again, ended up getting it, and just couldn't stop playing.
Funny thing was that a little before first playing the game, my friend told me that I'd be better off playing it in Easy, or even Casual difficulty because it was a tough game otherwise. I like the challange though. Did everything in Hard mode and don't regret one bit~ (it did take some time to get some of the bosses patterns though XD)

Another point that I found funny is that I like a lot games that *show* instead of *tellling* so even though i when I play I always prefer to choose Classic Mode over Adventure Mode, the story in Adventure Mode proved to be very fun too. gotta play it at least once~

I tell you, if you are a sonic fan, this is definitely a must. (and I challange you to play it on Hard Mode. It's fun! XD)
Even if you aren't a sonic fan but like platform games, you should still give it a try, i don't think you'd regret it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has reminded me of my long lost love for 2D platformers dating all the way back to the very first Sonic game. It really is a shame that this game is so criminally underrated, because the very second you start playing it you will feel how much love the developers have put into this jewel of a game.

If I were asked what I like most about it, I would not even know where to begin! You have fantastic, colourful 2D graphics, a mindblowingly good soundtrack and absolutely solid gameplay that does not need to hide behind landmark titles of the genre like Sonic, Rayman or Mega Man.

One of the bigger complaints I have heard about the game is the cheesy story mode and voice acting. If it's not to your liking you can also play the game in the classic mode, which reduces the story to short cutscenes similar to how they appear in Sonic & Knuckles for example. However, regarding the story and voice acting, I think it is ok, definitely not as bad as it is made out in most reviews. It is a bit on the cheesy side, but I think that actually has its own appeal that just works well in the context of the game.

If you want a well made, fun game that has a nice oldschool factor in it you absolutely have to buy this game, you will not regret it!

reviewText:
Although some parts were frustrating for me at the end, since I'm not spectacular at action platformers, I think this is quite possibly the most fun action platformer game that I've ever played, including classics like Sonic and the Mario games. At least for me, this games art style, story, enjoyable characters all with good voice acting, combat done well, enemy variety, story, music, atmosphere, setting, humor, and overall emotional investment the adventure mode allows the player to have with the characters all come together to make a very fun and enjoyable experience.

There is some cheesiness in some of the dialogue and story, but in a funny, well placed way. Beyond that, I feel like some of the different moves that can be pulled off can be a little awkward, but it depends on the control setup I suppose. All controls are easily rebindable, as is joystick sensitivity, so I might need to tweak that more, as some of the mild floatiness and jumping precision were probbly on my end, as everything else felt very tight.

One of the most fun aspects of the game for me was how much the overall style of presentation encourages a very go get 'em" attitude. The characters can take quite a number of hits before dying

reviewText: The first few levels are a bit slow, after that it's like someone lit the fuse on a rocket and nothing can stop it. Fast and furious platforming with great boss sections. The voice acting is significantly better that what you get in a Sonic game, which is helarous considering the budget difference. The cut scenes are rather long and numerous, but also quite a bit of fun. The plot is a bit confusing and sometimes makes me wonder if I'm expected to have see some movie beforehand.\n\nOverall though, the gameplay is very tight and has some interesting and inventive platforming ideas. Is it like a Sonic game? Only in so much as they're both sidescolling platformers centered around speed, this game has evolved past being a simple clone and is much better for it. And as icing on the cake the animation of the sprites is very endearing.

reviewText:
Nintendon't, Nintendon't, Nintendon't, 8Bit, 8Bit, 8Bit you hear it overall on steam pages about retro games. But here comes a game that reminds us that 8Bit are 8 to less! Pumped 16bit Genesis Action at its best!.

This game is highly Inspired by Genesis Classics like Sonic the Hedgehog, Rocket Night AKA Sparkster and much more (Which I haven't played so far but did you even play those two games? Those are Amazing!). I really love the giant Explosions which only are topped by Atari 2600 Explosions! I really love how the frame rate drops whenever you finish a boss! This Is Intentionally! It is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome because the same Happens with the Genesis AKA MegaDrive when you reach that point of explosion madness! Except you have an overclocked version maybe.
I recommend to turn this game on hard, never tried easy because as you expect it is on hard like Sparkster on Easy or maybe Medium! Which I find okay but after all the Original 16bit Era wasn't crazy difficult like the 8Bit, it was fun, challenging but not sadistic fun!. Another Improvement is the level Length which is just insane, remember the small stages at Rocket Knight Adventures? Or Maybe at Sonic the Hedgehog, well Sonic 2 hat some big Levels but those are huge and multiply that by several parts for each stage. This is madness! This is Awesome!

One thing I have to say, this is the ♥♥♥♥ing strangest Character design I've ever seen! But they just look like that is what they would have done at Team Sonic only by adding a bit more cocain!. But at least they are three girls, I love girls, I love girls who are kicking ♥♥♥♥ and those just kick ♥♥♥♥ allot!.

Buy this game, and enjoy if you ever had a Genesis this is a must have I only wish it was also available on the Genesis, maybe some crazy person will port it to like the sega cd.^^

And Remember:

GENESIS DOES WHAT NINTENDON'T!!!

reviewText: Trailer is pretty accurate.  It's similar to Sonic 3 and Knuckles but with new characters, abilities, levels, bosses, and a (long) storyline.  Also its updated with 2014 game mechanics.  Basically it's pretty awesome if you like classic platformers updated with modern conveniences (save points, more health, game customization, pause menu, less stage memorization and insta-death).
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is an excellent tribute to the Sega Genesis, borrowing elements from Sonic, Ristar and assorted Treasure games and putting them all together in a delightful, chalenging 16-bit adventure. Three different characters are playable, each with their own playstyles and story modes. In true 90s platformer tradition, the game gets significantly harder towards the end, and only serious gamers will be able to see the ending. A very aesthetically pleasing game as well. It has beautiful sprite artwork and animations, and its soundtrack is also top-notch.\n\nWithout a doubt this is one of the best, if not THE best indie platformer game on Steam. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
An impuse buy during the Steam Summer Sale while I was picking up Sonic 2 and Sonic 3 & Knuckles. Over all, I think it's nice and a good buy.

The characters are fully voiced which is new to me in games like this, but I will say sometimes they don't sound like they're fully reaching the kind of emotion they are trying to convey but it's still pretty good voice acting in my opinion.

I'm not one for graphics but this game looks like it tried to emulate Sonic's early days on the Dreamcast and Megadrive (I later heard that this was origonally a Sonic Fan Game so it's no wonder) and it does a fairly good job of doing that.

The game itself plays a lot like a Sonic Game from the Classic Era" especially when one plays as Lilac. As a result I keep trying to spindash when playing. However Lilac's ability that lets her bounce off the walls at high speeds is kind of hard to get a good sense on where you're going to go or even which direction you'll go as sometimes it seems like it doesn't matter.

The levels take me a fairly long time to beat but that's not nessicarily a bad thing
date: there's a fair amount of collectables I could go after if I so choosed and it's fairly liberal with it's checkpoints. Though I do wish there was a visual/audio cue letting me know that I hit a checkpoint
recommended: so that I don't have to worry about losing a signifigant amount of progress.\n\nThe boss battles are  immensely  fun. They are fast paced
hoursPlayed: straight forward
voteText: and give good visual cues when the boss is on it's last leg. However they are a tad unforgiving at times
helpfulPercent: the boss for Fortune Night has you dodging all many of lasers and explosives causing you to sometimes miss much needed health thrown to you by your allies. That being said I still enjoyed the battles greatly.\n\nThe music in the game is GREAT
votesHelpful: I bought the soundtrack with this game and I'm glad I did. Each one is fitting for the area and tone of the level. As well as the boss music pumping you up for the battle at hand.\n\nTL;DR  Freedom Planet is a overall fun game that might seem rough around the edges in some areas but is a good buy during a sale."

reviewText:
One part Sonic the Hedgehog, one part Rocket Knight Adventures - a genesis platformer that never was.

Fun, compelling, addictive. Also, difficulty curve ramps up steadily from a sleepwalk to a brutal gauntlet. Take breaks or you'll get blisters.

Surprisingly good voice acting. The writing is neither particularly strong nor particularly bad, but the voice acting is never the weak link.

There are three characters. Thus far I have played as two. They are very distinct and interesting for their distinction. Looking forward to the third.

Well worth your time if you enjoyed platformers on the genesis in your youth, or if you kind of wish you had.

If you really have an issue with the VA/story there's an option to play in Classic Mode without the cutscenes and stuff

reviewText:
Definitely play if you like a good platformer with action. The gameplay reminds me a bit of Sonic, a little of Cave Story, but it's mostly unique(or then I don't have very extenive experience with platformers). Gameplay, music, graphics, story, everything is there to put this up among my favourite 2D platformers. Bonus points for very good technical execution: runs perfectly on Linux, and supports game controllers entirely without problems.

There are a couple of little things that leave this just behind perfect. The voice acting is slightly inconsistent(it sounds like they were recorded in different studios or something, which makes it sound just slightly odd). The music volume is set too loud by default, it's hard to hear the talking. Setting it to about 80-90% is the best IMO. The controls feel kind of aggressive and floaty, but no big deal.

If you're unsure, just watch the video in the store and go from there. It's very representative.

reviewText: Rewarding both careful exploration and adrenaline-fueled speeding alike, Freedom Planet starts with the basics of 90s platforming and builds itself up from there (as opposed to beginning with today's platforming and sending it to the 90s). Truly, one of the greats among nostalgia-platformers

reviewText:
Amazing gameplay up until the bosses near the end, at which point attack telegraphing is infrequent (and often far too late to be useful) and becomes a case of dying tens of times to learn their attack pattern. Not really acceptable for an action game of this nature, this kind of difficulty belongs in the bullet hell genre.

Soundtrack is marvelous, cannot fault it at all. Voiceover is great (mostly) which a credit for an indie game, though the story was a bit lackluster and cutscenes are far too long. They break up the gameplay far too much.

Visuals are wonderful, real variety of environments and lots of interesting stuff in both the back and foreground. Particularly love the look of the stage 7 boss :)

Overall it's a fun game, worth playing if you enjoy similar titles.

reviewText:
Some of my earliest memories are from playing Sonic 2 on the Sega Genesis, and so when I saw this pop up in the summer sale, I figured it'd be worth a few bucks.  What I wasn't expecting was a flat-out improvement on the 2D Sonic formula in nearly every way, to the point which it's not even really a Sonic-clone".

+Huge levels with multiple intersecting paths
+3 different characters with very different mobility and combat options (including a unique level and some story differences for each)
+Gameplay varies consistently with new obstacles and enemies often enough to not feel repetitive
+Challenging
date: satisfying bosses\n+Soundtrack and artwork fit the intended style well\n+Story is simple
recommended: but effective at tying together the gameplay experiences (which is the point in this kind of thing)\n+I like the voice acting
hoursPlayed: but I've heard others complain so it may be a hit-or-miss situation\n\nAlso
voteText: it passes the Bechdel Test (for anyone who cares about that)."
votesHelpful: true
votesFunny: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Here's a quick tl;dr: If you enjoy platformers with a bit extra or came from the sega-genesis era of games, pick this one up.

A game that surprised me in more ways than one, quite honestly. I've always been attached to the platformer genre and this is one of my new favorites. I won't talk anything story or plot since you can find that in the game details, but I will talk about the good. Mechanically, it works, and it's solid, and that's a lot more than what games on steam have nowadays. This next opinion is disagreeable, but I found the VA and story to be extremely enticing, with Milla being one of my favorite all time characters. Most of the characters are actually rather memorable, with Brevon being presented as one of the best villains I've seen in a long time, almost Vaas or Handsome Jack levels. Believe me, by the end of the story mode, he's done more things to you and your friends to make the game take a seriously dark turn. And I loved every second of it. If you wish, you can play the stages sonic-style (classic mode), with just the levels and very minimal cutscene stuffs. Though I don't recommend classic, as you'll be missing the story.

Although I make this game sound like a perfect game (no game is however), it does have it's flaws, as with most games. Some VA was superb and very well done, Brevon for example. On the other hand, some is... not great. Nothing dealbreaking though. There are few bugs thankfully, no serious fatal bugs that I've experienced. Slightly strange physics, there is a lack of momentum when running up walls, you can do it from almost a dead stop. I didn't really care all that much though.

Do I recommend it? I do. I got it during the summer sale, but I've dropped enough time to say I would have payed full price for it. I also recommend the sound track. It was fantastic, absolutely amazing. Buying the game for it alone might be worth it.

Late P.S.: Last I saw on the steam guides, there is an in-game mod to remove the voices from the cutscenes in the story mode. Huge plus for those that want the story but not the VA. Isn't it awesome to have options? Lastly, Devs are giving free content in the future. Supposed to drop sometime around the end of this summer.

reviewText: If you like Genesis-era Sonic the Hedgehog games, you'll probably enjoy Freedom Planet.  Like the original Sonic games, it's a platformer that rewards high speed as well as precision.  Unlike Sonic, the characters in Freedom Planet have a reserve of life to absorb a little punishment, and special attacks beyond simply new ways to jump onto or roll into enemies (in fact, simply attempting to hop on an enemy's head won't generally hurt it).   The difficulty of the stages is very nice and ramps up over a nice curve, and while some of the bosses are fantastically brutal, they're mostly the ones towards the end of the game.  The game's pretty generous with unmarked checkpoints, too, and as far as I can tell you have unlimited continues.\n\nIt's not the world's longest game, but then neither was Sonic 2, and Freedom Planet features multiple characters and play modes to add in a little extra value.  What's more, there's actually quite a bit of story, and all of it is fully voice acted, and pretty well voice acted at that.  There's a ton of love and effort that went into this game, and it really shows with how they tell the story (which is, itself, is rather stylized but very good at being what it wants to be and in my opinion wholly enjoyable).
